name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 and Own Resources: citizens' expectations should now be met (2019/2833(RSP)). Before I open the debate, I would like to inform you that we are still testing a new system whereby Members can register spontaneous speeches and blue cards electronically. You have received information by e-mail about using this system and the instructions are on your table. Members may use the function keys on their electronic voting systems to submit a request for a speech. Please note that, in parallel with the use of the electronic system, a "standard registration" (by raising a white sheet of paper or by personally registering with colleagues in plenary at the beginning of the debate for spontaneous speeches and by lifting up a blue card for the blue card procedure) is also possible. I would therefore politely remind you to bring your voting card so that you can use this system. Registration by e-mail is not possible. If you want to register an impromptu speech, you can do so now. You do not have to wait until the end of the debate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the next multiannual financial framework (MFF) will set the stakes for the financing of EU policies until 2027.  Our aim is a balanced financial framework that reflects both new priorities and traditional policies and contributes to the common European objectives. It is not too easy to achieve these substantial aims, but we are working hard. The timetable is also challenging us. Even though we are in the middle of the institutional change, the Presidency will do its best to finalise the Council negotiations by the end of the year. I am personally very committed to this target.  Today’s plenary debate gives me a unique and concrete opportunity to cooperate with Parliament. I personally chair the General Affairs Council meetings, but I also represent the Council in every plenary session during our Presidency, which gives us an opportunity to have an up-to-date discussion regularly.  In the spirit of good interinstitutional cooperation and in line with the approach outlined by the Bulgarian Presidency, we are committed to continuing the established practice of holding an exchange of views before and after sessions of the General Affairs Council (GAC) when the MFF is on its agenda.  Now a few words on the EU’s challenges and our common priorities. The next MFF is to respond to Europe’s current and future challenges by increasing the share of expenditure in policy areas with the highest European added-value.  For decades, traditional policies have been supporting EU integration by fostering convergence and development as well as maintaining high standard agriculture in Europe. We can see the positive results of these investments across the Union and they will continue to foster convergence and support transition towards a sustainable agriculture. Rural development funding plays a crucial role here. One of the key challenges of our time is climate change. We already see its impact on our environment and it is set only to worsen if we do not step up our efforts. Many voices – firstly, the one of our youth – call upon us to do more. The MFF will be essential to this purpose, as it will cover the period leading towards the 2030 climate targets deadline. On climate, Member States seem to support the 25% mainstreaming target, even if some see it as the maximum and others as the minimum.  Further to the EU’s climate target on energy transition aiming for carbon neutrality, as a Presidency we see that there is the need for a fund to facilitate fair transition towards carbon neutrality. The MFF will also better support innovation and research, at a time when society is undergoing massive changes due to the digital transformation. Europe needs to stay at the forefront of research, development and innovations.  The future MFF needs to be aligned with new priorities. Managing migration requires a comprehensive approach. By providing funding and using different MFF headings, it will be possible to better respond both to international and external aspects of migration. At the same time, our expectations must be grounded in reality.  One of the biggest EU Member States is set to leave the Union.  I have had consultations with the ministers of all Member States, and in this context, many have expressed the need for the EU budget to reflect this new reality. As the Presidency, this is an element that we have to take into account. As for own resources, they must provide a fair, transparent and equitable system for the financing of the next MFF and to limit the administrative burden for the Member States.  From the Presidency’s point of view, on new own resources the non-recycled plastic packaging waste proposal seems to gain the strongest support, and a positive approach from the majority of Member States. As far as new own resources are concerned, we need to keep in mind that also here a consensus between all Member States is needed.  Now defending European values starts from respect for the rule of law within the Union, and above all, in its Member States. Rule of law is not a political declaration but a legal norm. From the Presidency’s perspective, Article 2 of the Treaty concerning the rule of law will not stay in force by itself, and this should be reflected in our policy work. Rule of law is a crucial element in the next MFF as it includes the proposal on protecting the Union budget from rule-of-law deficiencies. That proposal applies equally to all Member States and all EU funds, just like the rule of law itself.  Rule of law and democracy form the foundation of European freedom, security and prosperity. Respect for the rule of law is self-evidently linked to the legitimacy and proper functioning of the EU. One of the priorities of the Finnish Presidency is to ensure protection of the rule of law and to reinforce its links to the budget. Following the leaders’ guidance, we will continue our work on this important matter. I am convinced that there is a way to create a balanced and legally sound instrument based on the Commission’s proposal.  I am aware of the concerns of Members of this Parliament on the timeline. So far, the Presidency’s work within the Council has focused on listening to the Member States and their priorities. Now there will be an opportunity for the leaders to give the Presidency direct guidance.  To this end, the Presidency is preparing a paper that will facilitate the first substantial discussion of the leaders in October’s European Council. Obviously, this will depend on the reactions of delegations and above all, on the way President Tusk will want to conduct the discussion. On the basis of the leaders’ guidance, we will prepare a finalised draft negotiation box with numbers to facilitate an agreement by the end of the year, as concluded by the European Council in June this year.  I would like to underline once more that the Presidency is fully committed to meeting this timetable and we will do our utmost to facilitate the final stages of the MFF negotiations. It is also fundamental for us to cooperate with you in line with the previous Presidencies and to progress on sectoral MFF proposals with a view of reaching additional common understandings. Thank you very much for your attention and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, indeed, I had made a point of order and he is having a point in the middle of this discussion. I am concerned about a number of events that took place yesterday during the election of the Cariforum delegation's office. Ms. Maxette Pirbakas, who is an elected member of our Identity and Democracy group, was appointed on 17 July as a member of this Cariforum delegation. While she has been a full member of this delegation since July, we have learned from the administration of our European Parliament that she cannot stand for election because she would suddenly no longer be a full member of the Cariforum delegation. She is a candidate for the first vice-presidency under this Rule of Hondt, even if she is not respected, and nothing should be able to prevent her from running. After the sometimes somewhat disturbing comments that had been made about a cordon sanitaire that would prevent us from accessing posts, is this reversal, which does not respect a decision taken in plenary, a desire to systematically exclude the members of the Group Identity and Democracy, or is it a mistake? If so, I hope it will be repaired soon. It is important that Mrs Pirbakas, who is one of the few elected representatives from the French overseas and therefore from the European overseas, can be a candidate in this election.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to say to Mr Rivice that there is a reason why the committees elect. There is an agreement between the political groups which is not laid down in the Rules of Procedure and in which the groups decide. Of course, political considerations also come into play. With regard to the first point you have made, anyone who is a full member can stand for election and we will follow up on that part of your speech. Their concerns were divided into two parts. I will look into the first concern because it is a formal point set out in the Rules of Procedure. If the colleague is a full member, she must be allowed to stand for election. The question of whether she will be elected is a completely different question.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Mr President, I also wanted to speak on respect for the Hondt rule. What happened last week in the Committee on Foreign Affairs is quite surprising. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has awarded thirteen permanent reports, that is, for the five years of that mandate. These thirteen reports are not insignificant, since they concern thirteen countries that are linked to the European Union either by neighbourhood agreements or through a pre-accession process. These thirteen reports were divided into only three groups, i.e. the ECR, GUE and ID groups were totally excluded, and we are told that these reports do not fit into the calculation of the Hondt rule. One day, however, you would have to know when this rule applies and when it does not apply. Again, it is still something totally discriminatory because I think that out of thirteen reports, we could have respected a little proportionality.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Mariani. Here, too, my answer relates to the second part of the reply for Mr Rivice. The Rules of Procedure only provide for a balance. Ultimately, the decision takes place in the committees. In any case, I see no reason for a prima vista to follow up on your intervention here. Your group is, of course, free to address the President.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I thank you for the opportunity to react to the European Parliament’s political resolution on the next EU long-term budget. I salute your engagement on this file of strategic importance which will help shape the future of the European Union over the coming decade.  I also recognise the intense work carried out by this Parliament, in particular the co—rapporteurs and negotiating team appointed by the Chair of the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) Mr van Overtveldt – Ms Marques, Ms Hayer, Mr Olbrycht, Mr Fernandes and Mr Andresen – to bring forward this political resolution now. The European Council will hold an exchange of views on the next multiannual financial framework next week and I can only encourage the leaders and the Council Presidency to take into due consideration the European Parliament’s positions.  The interim report that Parliament adopted in November last year was a substantial contribution to the negotiations on the next multiannual financial framework. One year later, and after the European elections of May, it was essential to leave absolutely no ambiguity about the continuity of Parliament’s stance. I therefore welcome that this political resolution largely endorses the position already expressed in 2018. I also take note of the new elements that this political resolution brings forward. I will address them in a minute. But before doing so, I would like to recall the Commission’s position on the overall level of expenditure. It is certainly one of the issues, if not the issue, that steers the ongoing negotiations the most.  Parliament would like to set the next EU long—term budget at the level of 1.3% of the EU27 GNI. At the other end of the spectrum, several Member States have been repeatedly calling for a budget limited to 1% of the EU27 GNI. I believe we all need to address those divergences. All institutions need to be active and constructive in seeking a compromise. At the end of the day, there will need to be an agreement on the next EU long-term budget, and the sooner the better. We urgently need to make progress in the negotiations and avoid entrenched positions. We must acknowledge that the Union is asked to do more and better on its political priorities. This requires a modern budget focused on EU added value, and more resources for programmes contributing, for example, to climate action, research and innovation, digital security, border management, etc. On the other hand, we cannot escape reality. The Union will lose an important contributor to the EU budget so that moderate savings in the biggest spending areas – cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy – are inevitable. In the light of those two constraints, what the Commission has proposed for the next multiannual financial framework, with an overall level of 1.114% of EU27 GNI, is balanced and realistic. I remain convinced that it would be a fair outcome for all. On top of endorsing most of Parliament’s position expressed last year, this political resolution also adds a limited number of new elements.  First and foremost, let me address the point on the financing of the President—elect’s political guidelines. You will understand that they cannot infringe upon the next College prerogative. However, the Commission’s proposal of May last year and the ongoing negotiations already provide a solid framework for these priorities. The Budgetary Instrument for Convergence and Competitiveness for the euro area is one element. Another one, the rule of law, is an integral part of the next EU long-term budget: EUR 120 billion on external action investment, a closer partnership with Africa and a strengthening of the European Defence Fund with a 22—fold increase compared to the current pilot and preparatory actions, which means in absolute figures, from EUR 590 million to EUR 13 billion.  For other initiatives, I cannot anticipate on the detailed content of the new initiatives. It’s essential to continue the MFF negotiations with speed and determination. They provide for an opportunity to translate the political guidelines of the President—elect into action and accommodate them within the framework of the MFF agreement. We must avoid damaging delays in the launch of the new programmes that are in the clear interest of our regions, our researchers, our small businesses, our farmers and our young people. Let me now address the issue of climate change and Parliament’s call for a more ambitious quantified target in relation to climate—related expenditure.  The Commission is committed to delivering on the Paris Agreement on climate change and to making the Union lead by example on the global stage. That’s why we have proposed to set ourselves a high objective and to dedicate 25% of the overall next EU long-term budget, or approximately EUR 320 billion, to projects contributing to climate action. That is ambitious and credible too.  The target of 25% is based on our experience and on our bottom—up assessment of how much each and every spending programme can actually contribute to climate action. Some programmes and funds will contribute significantly to climate action. Some others among them – also those for which you propose further reinforcement like the single market, Erasmus, Creative Europe or the European Social Fund (ESF) will not.  Any target higher than 25% would require a difficult choice. For instance, the climate objective of those programmes that already contribute to climate action could be increased. In practice, this would require mostly much higher targets within the common agricultural policy, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund because of their critical mass in the budget or, in relative terms, the overall share of the budget allocated to programmes that don’t contribute to climate action could be decreased. In practice, this would mostly affect the European Social Fund and other reinforced or new priorities, such as Erasmus, defence, security and border management. That is the harsh mathematical alternative that we are facing. I acknowledge Parliament’s intention to exercise its rights fully and I can say that I can relate to the feeling of impatience expressed by some Members that, one and a half years after the Commission proposal, the Council has not yet agreed on its position on the MFF. Please be assured that the Commission is fully committed to facilitating dialogue. We will continue to provide both Parliament and the Council with the technical information to support transparency, openness and constructive cooperation. Finally, the resolution calls on the Commission to present a contingency plan for early 2020 to ensure continuity until the next EU long-term budget is agreed. It will be up to the incoming Commission to respond to your call but, as you rightly point out, the Treaty in its Article 312 and also the MFF Regulation itself, provide the relevant legal framework if an agreement cannot be reached. Now is not the time to consider any additional measures. For the moment, our priority and focus must remain to reach a timely agreement on the new multiannual financial framework and sectoral basis acts.  Finally, let me thank this House for your continuous firm support to reform of the own resources system, to maintaining the flexibility of the MFF and to introducing a mechanism aimed at protecting the EU budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law. I agree with Members of this Parliament that it’s high time to decide and meet citizens’ expectations. We all have a collective responsibility to agree on the next EU long-term budget on time so that the next generation of programmes is operational on 1 January 2021.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Minister, i would like to thank you very much for Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Time is running out! Time is running out and universities, businesses, local authorities, students who want to use Erasmus are waiting for information on what will happen to the budget after 2020. Will there be this budget or will it not be, and what will be the decisions? When will decisions be made?  I think it is worth recalling that the European Commission started both with its general report on scenarios and with its proposal in May 2018. Now it's been a year and a half since then. Parliament has tried very quickly to respond to this proposal, even though the procedure provided for in the Treaty does not give Parliament such opportunities at this stage. Parliament, on the other hand, presented its position in a sense of responsibility in November, and this is a realistic position. We have taken all the information and data from what the European Commission has presented. We didn't create anything. We agreed on the new priorities, we said that horizon 2020 needs to be strengthened in the future as it is today, and we need to strengthen, for example, Erasmus. We have stated this as a political position, but we believe that so-called traditional policies cannot be reduced quite mechanically. We are aware of the cost of leaving the UK, and today Parliament says: Time is running out, we need decisions, not just – otherwise sympathetic and nice – meetings on the exchange of information. We are ready to cooperate, but we look forward to working together to actually give our consent at the end.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Minister Tytti Tuppurainen, Commissioner Hahn, I would like to begin by highlighting the title of this resolution: 'It is time to meet the expectations of the citizens'. That's what we're here for. We have an obligation to provide for financial means to match the Union's political commitments and ambitions.  With this resolution, Parliament confirms its position in the November 2018 progress report, but now with renewed legitimacy. It updates the negotiating mandate, respecting the election results of May 2019. It values the climate, reiterates that the next Multiannual Financial Framework should be set at 1.3% of the EU's Gross National Income to 27. This figure alone makes it possible to continue to robustly support cohesion policies and agricultural policy, but also innovation and investment, migration policy, foreign and defence policy or the implementation of a strong European pillar of social rights.  We support the principle of integrating climate issues into all policies and a fair transition to a carbon-neutral economy, based on the highest criteria of social justice, without leaving anyone behind.  We call for the creation of a new mechanism to protect the european union's budget where the rule of law is not respected.  We welcome the political commitments made by Mrs Van der Leyen on additional initiatives, but we reiterate that for new initiatives new money. We are waiting for a concrete proposal on the European Green Pact. We welcome the commitments made by the President-elect to relaunch legislative proposals in order to build a basket of new own resources. It will be a good time for a reform of the European Union's funding system, aligned with the main political priorities.  Parliament is ready to start negotiations on budget 21-27 and own resources. It is time for the Council to open negotiations with Parliament on the budget and on aspects of sectoral legislation establishing the new EU programmes, as well as the rule of law proposal. Without delay, we must reach a solid agreement that avoids a time gap between the end of this financial framework and the beginning of the next and that meets the expectations of citizens.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, rest assured that we will be following the discussions of the next European summit closely. The reason is simple: Parliament is getting impatient. In May 2018, 17 months ago, the Commission presented its proposal for the next financial framework. Parliament immediately got to work and expressed its position and priorities. Since then, we have been waiting for the Commission to move forward and decide on a number of cases. However, time is running out and the time has come to move to the next level in the negotiations. It is also time to involve Parliament. The line adopted by Parliament is clear and we reaffirm today its priorities with the maintenance of the budget of the Common Agricultural and Cohesion Policy, the strengthening of emblematic programmes such as Erasmus or Horizon 2020, new appropriations for new challenges or the establishment of a mechanism linked to the rule of law. The next framework will also have to respond to climate change and preserve biodiversity. On this issue, the commitment of President-elect Ursula von der Leyen, with the launch of a Green deal and the introduction of a carbon tax at borders, in particular, is encouraging. One point of warning, however, is that these initiatives, which we welcome, must be accompanied by additional budgetary resources. I am already hearing here and there the irresponsible attacks on Parliament, which would always like to spend more, but let us be concrete: with a constant envelope, more initiatives, it means cuts in other programmes, sometimes dusting and therefore less effective public policies. Let's not give the Eurosceptics some ground to grind. I will conclude with my own resources. The revenue system, as it was designed in the 1970s, has been misguided over time. Today, the predominance of national contributions fuels the logic of fair return. In other words, we have a system in which national approaches are king, even though we should be focusing on European added value. There is an urgent need to move forward on this issue, which, I recall, is essential for Parliament. We will not agree on the expenditure framework without new own resources for the Union. Madam Minister, you know, the ball is in your court. You know our positions, we are waiting for yours, so that we can finally start discussions in the service of the Europeans.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The climate crisis, social division or even digitalisation: we can no longer solve all the major issues of the future at national level. We need a strong European Union for this and we Greens want a strong European Union. We want an EU that is ready to give all people a future and is climate neutral in 20 years' time. To do this, we need to change the EU, and we need to invest massively. The financial framework offers us the right chance for this right now, and so let me be very clear at the outset: the position of the German Federal Government and of many other Member States is damaging Europe. It is populist simply to stand up for a 1% budget and fight for a small budget. The German Federal Government and others are acting anti-European. We expect more from German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Federal Finance Minister Olaf Scholz in particular! We expect them to stand up courageously for a strong Europe and not simply put the brakes on everything. We do not understand this regular table position. After all, whoever cuts the EU budget destroys our climate. Those who cut the EU budget accept that the social divisions on our continent are deepening, and those who cut the EU budget will be less able to invest in research, fast internet and Erasmus programmes. Most of the EU budget is still spent on climate-damaging agricultural subsidies – we need to change that! Instead of mass animal husbandry, mass production, we want to promote environmental protection and animal welfare. We want to invest in renewable energy, public transport and better European rail links. Social and environmental investment is a part of us, and for us Greens, it is one of the biggest scandals in the European Union that more than 120 million people on our continent have to live in poverty. We cannot accept this and we, as the European Union, must do more to combat poverty. That is why we are particularly pleased that we have succeeded in achieving broad agreement in Parliament's negotiating team on the financial framework on important positions, that we stand together here in Parliament on the major issues, that we are prepared to act and that we will enter into tough negotiations with the Council together, because we have to negotiate hard. It is about our future, it is about the future of all people in the European Union.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been discussing the next Multiannual Financial Framework in this House and in the Committee on Budgets for several months now, but progress seems to me to be quite insufficient. To date, despite the Finnish Presidency's commitment to close an agreement by the end of the year, there is no room for agreement on the horizon. This, in my view, is mainly because we are not looking at the next financial framework pragmatically and because the majority in this Parliament has a totally utopian approach to what the next Multiannual Financial Framework should be. Many more resources are being asked, eur 200 billion more, to finance certain programmes and some new priorities. I believe that in order to reach an agreement we need to return to pragmatism and ask ourselves a question: if every time we have to negotiate the budget, the Multiannual Financial Framework, we ask for more resources and the Member States do not want to put them, obviously there is a reason. If an investment is good, I think lenders are happy to put in more resources. If they do not want to put them, it is quite clear why, namely that they do not consider programmes and spending lines to be efficient in pursuing those objectives.  Above all, I am concerned about a drift, namely the fact that the next proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework is imapped with conditionality, conditionalities that will make this instrument an undemocratic instrument and put spending and allocation decisions at the mercy of some Brussels bureaucrat. Last question about own resources. Let us begin by calling them by their own name: own resources are new illegitimate taxes that Brussels would like to put on the citizens of Europe. This is not the right approach and we will never reach agreement on this to make this instrument an instrument at the service of the citizens and not an instrument of political blackmail.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, for the Presidency, – Mr President, honourable Presidency, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Ney Dear Commissioner, The name of the resolution is excellent. Time to meet expectations: citizens' expectations from the multiannual budget. However, it is clear that these expectations are contradictory. In some countries, the majority of citizens believe that the budget should be higher. In other countries, it is considered that contributions should, of course, be lower and as little as possible. And it is also clear that, following the emergence of a proposal from the European Commission in several Member States, in cohesion countries, there was, in fact, disappointment from the fact that, even then, the total reduction in Brexit is much smaller in expenditure than what we get in our offer in the cohesion envelope. In other words, Brexit is often blamed as a reason, although that is not the real reason. Or, in agriculture, citizens expect compensation payments in the form of direct payments to actually equalise, because fertiliser or fuel costs equally in all countries of the European Union. And also in her speech, what Mrs von der Leyen mentioned about the European Commission's new initiatives is to be understood as to whether additional resources are expected from the proposal of the new European Commission or whether there are any other reactions, or whether it squeezes even more of the expenditure on existing projects. And finally, even the position that grew in development and research— it is clear that the devil is in the details. The question is how this money will be divided, where she will settle, where there will be development and where, on the contrary, the decline in the Member States.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, my group considers the Commission's proposals for the new multiannual financial framework to be inadequate and the cuts proposed — even in the Commission's weak proposal — by the Council are unacceptable. We also consider it dangerous to delay and to resent the Council, which for a year and a half has had a dossier and is not moving forward with it, while Parliament has done its duty in full.  We consider the Commission's proposal inadequate and unacceptable the Council's attitude, not only in terms of the amount of the budget, where Parliament is calling for a more ambitious budget to tackle the climate crisis, to strengthen the social agenda, employment and the shift from austerity to sustainable development, but also in terms of the internal allocation of these funds. Because it is provocative, unfair and absurd to multiply — as Mr Hahn has confessed — 22 times defence spending and to cut spending on the Common Agricultural Policy and cohesion and not to give the money needed to achieve the ambitious targets we set to tackle the climate crisis.

name: Richard TICE
text: – Mr President, the Treaty on the European Union prevents the allocation of EU budget for defence spending. Yet in this financial framework, some EUR 27 billion have been allocated to defence, including a 22-fold increase for the European Defence Fund. Outside this budget, using other budgets, Member States contribute to the EU Peace Facility and PESCO, as well as the EU Defence Agency. It is quite clear, despite assurances to the contrary, that the EU is looking to create and build an EU army. The United Kingdom wants nothing to do with an EU army, and that is one of the many benefits of leaving the European Union. Although Member States seem to find this money for these defence contributions, only six Member States meet their NATO obligations to pay 2% of GDP. If wealthy countries like Germany and Italy cannot meet their obligations for NATO, why should they expect NATO to come to their assistance in their hour of need if they won’t pay.  (Applause)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, Parliament is united, Parliament is waiting for the Council once again, a Council which advances the snail's pass. The President-in-Office of the Council is not even attentive to Parliament's positions, it shows once again her disrespect for the citizens of the European Union.  We want to maintain cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy, fisheries, traditional policies and, at the same time, increase research, innovation, climate support, support for young people, Erasmus+, priorities that the Council also says are its own.  By adding the policies, we have 1.3% of gross national income. It's nothing extraordinary. Furthermore, it is clear that we will only give our consent to the Multiannual Financial Framework if we have broad agreement on the new own resources, which should bring transparency, which should also bring simplification, which should help mitigate national transfers. New own resources that cannot burden citizens either, and tax harmonisation is essential there. These are the Commission's accounts: one billion euros lost in tax fraud and evasion and avoidance.  We can have a budget that I will not say ambitious, but in terms of citizens' expectations.  The citizens ask, the Council almost always rejects, the Commission and this Commissioner help, Parliament will force it.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister. Today we are debating this resolution on the financial framework, which is more important than ever, judging by the echoes that are coming to us from the Council. This Parliament has already taken a very clear position a year ago on what the next financial framework should look like. A reasoned position based on needs, priorities and political commitments and quantifying how much the European budget should amount to – hence that 1.3%. We also take a very clear position, saying that the European budget cannot depend almost exclusively on the contributions of the Member States and that a new financing system based on the internal market, fair taxation and the fight against climate change must therefore be established. And in this new resolution we want to put four themes on the table. The first is that this Parliament confirms what the previous Parliament adopted in 2018. The second, that the fight against the climate emergency needs a greater commitment than we had last year. The third, which President-elect Von der Layen and many of the Commissioners who have been at the hearings, have committed to this House to launch a number of initiatives which are not yet covered by the Commission's proposal and which we have therefore called for a review. And finally, and we have all said, that we have been waiting for the Council for a year; that we're not going to accept any agreement just because we're running out of time. And yes, that's why we've called for transitional measures. We already know that the Treaty envisages them, but then in practice it is much more complicated, so let us work.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased to be able to make my first speech here in the European Parliament as rapporteur for the Renew Group for the multiannual financial framework. This IS because, with this EU financial framework, we are setting the priorities for the policy of the coming years. I believe that this EU budget must be geared towards the future and, above all, to the future, and must bring real European added value. We are able to achieve this above all by providing the EU with a large budget for big issues and a small budget for small issues and by setting priorities. For me, one of the major European issues is the promotion and management of digitisation, support for research, more Erasmus, the fight against climate change and, above all, the fight against terrorism and the protection of our external borders.  However, in the negotiations on the financial framework, my group will pay particular attention to one thing: it is not acceptable for European funds to be taken, but that European fundamental values and rules are subsequently trampled underfoot. The EU is a community of values and those who do not support the fundamental values in the EU should no longer receive monetary support from the EU in the future. With us, Renew Europe, there will be no discount to the rule of law and fundamental values in the EU, and that is what we will be working for in these budget negotiations. We want a financial framework that actually takes this into account.

name: David CORMAND
text: Mr President, our choices in the coming decade will be decisive for the climate. Europe has a historical responsibility and must have a budget that is up to the challenge. The text presented this morning is progressing. In particular, I welcome the explicit mention of compliance with the Paris targets for the 2021-2027 budget. But we have to go further. How can they be translated in practice if no numerical targets are included in the next MFF? This is the battle we intend to wage. It is good news that Parliament only approves the MFF if the own resources part is reviewed and strengthened. This issue is crucial if we are to save the climate. With this in mind, we will defend the creation of taxes on financial transactions, kerosene and carbon, because the status quo is no longer possible. We need a new deal with the Member States. For two euros collected by these taxes, which the states do not know how to collect, one euro will go into the state coffers and the remaining euro will be paid into the European budget, to support the green investments we need. The budget must once again become a tool in the service of a policy that guarantees human rights and respect for the planet.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as I read the proposal for a joint resolution, I quickly understood that everything was an excuse to increase the European Union's budget. In France, the "En Marche" parties and the Republicans, always so quick to defend the rationalisation of spending and tax cuts on the national stage, here in the European Parliament, support an unprecedented increase in the budget that will lead to an explosion of the French contribution. EUR 1,324 billion is the budget you are asking for for the next multi-year financial framework 2021-2027, an increase of 40% over the previous MFF. In economics, this is called the ratchet effect, that is, the total inability of a bureaucratic institution like the European Union to reduce its budget when it reaches a certain threshold, that is, not agreeing to want to go back. The legitimate question is: who will benefit from this new financial windfall: our farmers, our entrepreneurs, SMEs, which are suffering the consequences of unfair competition exacerbated by the proliferation of free trade treaties? To that question, we are answering, certainly not. I quote your text: these additional resources are needed to deal with new responsibilities, for example, in the areas of migration, external action and defence. On this text, of course, we will not comment. On the other hand, when it comes to creating new sources of revenue, there you are overflowing with imagination with, for example, the removal of the collection charges charged by Member States on customs duties or the introduction in the budget of the revenue generated by fines and penalties or the contribution related to plastic. On the contrary, the resolution of the Identity and Democracy group, of which I am a member, is pragmatic with two proposals to remember. The first is to limit the next MFF to 1% of the EUROPEAN Union's GNI 27.... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Adopting the Multiannual Financial Framework is our great task. The European Parliament has a negotiating mandate for both expenditure and revenue in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. We therefore demand negotiations that take account of real problems and needs in order to reach a solid agreement in a timely way. In our opinion, the Commission should prepare a contingency plan in the event of delays in the adoption of the new financial framework. The contingency plan, which extends the current financial framework, will help protect european Union beneficiaries. This resolution should be supported as soon as possible in order to move on to negotiations. Referring to the likely future basket of new resources, we would like to recall that any new initiative must comply with the principles set out in Protocol No 28 to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, so that it is not regressive to partners and beneficiaries.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, yesterday, in front of the Committee of the Regions, I was saying that a small budget for Europe would be a cruel lack of political ambition. Sacrificing the common agricultural policy, sacrificing the cohesion policy would be a terrible renunciation and would ultimately give a victory to the Europhobes. Is that what the heads of state want? Is that the lesson they learned from the European elections? That's the question I'm asking them. And I say to the Council that the European Parliament will not accept cuts in the cohesion budget because, more than ever, we need more cohesion and cuts in the cohesion budget will be less training for young people, it will be less innovation, it will be less investment in the regions, it will be less jobs , it will be less food aid for the poorest and it will be more territorial divide. So, at a time when a global crisis seems to be brewing, the best way to protect European citizens is to provide the European Union with a real budget, an offensive political budget, which is also able to meet the challenges we face, particularly with regard to climate change.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner, the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Budget of the European Union must be developed and ensure equal prosperity for all Member States. Economically developed countries are achieving greater economic activity due to market expansion, while certain less developed countries such as Croatia are at risk of membership in the European Union. In terms of agricultural economic production alone, the Republic of Croatia lost three and a half billion euros in five years, from 2013 to 2018, while during that same period, for example Romania, it generated a plus of sixteen billion euros. The Republic of Croatia, therefore, has provided 1.8 billion euros since its membership in the European Union, and has lost 3.5 billion in the farm itself. Therefore, it is logical to require economically developed countries to contribute more to the European budget.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Minister and the Commissioner to Parliament. We are debating today the next Multiannual Financial Framework at a very important moment in time, and we are reconfirming the position of Parliament in light of the results of the European elections. We have seen people come out and vote in large numbers, expecting Europe to do more – students, researchers, farmers, people in the cities and in the villages, people who expect more security, and people who expect us to innovate, to research more and better deliver on digital, and to tackle climate change – and it is our duty to listen to them and to deliver it to them. People expect more, and we should do more.  My first message to you, Minister, is that we cannot do more with much less. In the previous MFF, the philosophy was that if we need to do something new, if we need to allocate money for something, we take it away from something else. EFSI was created, but the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 suffered, and examples can continue. This philosophy has to end. New priorities have to be financed with new resources. Otherwise, we need to tell students that there are fewer Erasmus scholarships, and farmers that the subsidies are smaller. We should not do that.  Secondly, Minister, my question to you is this: when and what are you ready to negotiate with Parliament? What we have seen so far from the Finnish Presidency is too little, and it is too weak. We need political commitment at the highest level now. Parliament will, with a large majority, adopt its position now. We need to sit down, and it’s your responsibility to come and talk to Parliament. Otherwise – and I have to say it very clearly – the Council will be blamed by the beneficiaries of Europe for us not being able to finance them on 1 January 2021.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a general premise and two very quick points. The premise is that the resolution is very good. I support the idea of strongly reaffirming Parliament's position and the ambition to have a courageous budget for the next seven years. Paragraph 5, which introduces the review of own resources as a strategic objective, is very good.  The two points. It is very important to link the revenue side with the expenditure side in any budget, as you said positively at the hearing. Budgetary policy is not just a bureaucratic exercise, it is not a test of mathematics, it is the way in which we allocate resources to respond to the problems of our citizens, it is the heart of our democracies, without which democracies do not stand. That is why, if the objectives are ambitious – ecological transition, youth employment, research, structural funds – we must link income that is genuinely European. That is the first point. Secondly, we need a cultural change, a leap forward. Transforming European revenues does not mean demanding more taxes from citizens, but rather reducing the net contributions of the people and creating a Europeanisation of taxes, an integrated vision of revenue and finally not sovereignism.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner! Dear Minister Tuppurainen! In one minute, not many good advice can be given to the Finnish Presidency, but there are perhaps four.  Firstly, we must cope with the hole britain leaves behind. It will require a little solidarity and a little more money from the Member States. Secondly, we need the conditions for innovation and technology. This means that we must stick to all the promises we have made so far about money for research.  The third issue concerns something that others have also talked about here, that is, investment is necessary. The gap that Europe has in terms of investment is worryingly large, and if we cannot manage these investments, we cannot manage the rest of what we have set out to do. The fourth point is about fair solutions. We have major differences between the Member States in terms of financial and scientific technical resources. If we are unable to overcome them, we will not meet our challenges either.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank Mr Andresen. I learned something about it. I have learned that the Council, if it does not want increases, is populist. I like to be a populist, if that is the definition of populism, because we do not want to spend more money. But what is populism? In this case, figures have been mentioned again and again. It is always said that the Commission wants 1.14% of national income, and Parliament wants 1.3% of national income. That sounds very harmless, these are small numbers. But if we convert that, that is just 11% and that is 30%, and you should say that to the citizens, to the citizens whose expectations you want to meet. We are talking about the citizens, and if we are constantly talking about increases and the citizen does not want that, then I believe that we are simply sand in their eyes, and we do not want that.

name: Henrik OVERGAARD NIELSEN
text: – (inaudible) acknowledges that the UK is leaving the EU, and that the UK’s net contribution of EUR 75 to 100 billion is not included for the next seven years. Due to the repatriation of democracy to the UK, we will not be party to the scrapping of all the rebates, including the UK one, the increase in tax—raising powers of the EU, and the increased spending on a European army. This Parliament wants to increase the proposed budget by almost 20%, while the take-home pay for workers has hardly gone up in the last 10 years.  (Applause in some quarters) That is a disgrace and entirely ignores, with breathtaking arrogance, the realities of your constituents’ lives and struggles. May I suggest that this Parliament starts repaying the trust put in it by European taxpayers and takes a leading role in saving the EU taxpayer some money? Let’s start with getting rid of the 130 chauffeur-driven limos and having allowances paid on production of receipts, reflecting the normal practice expected in any company across Europe. (Applause)

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. With regard to the multiannual financial framework, when I hear the various expectations here, I believe that Parliament's position is a fairly reasonable one. It is reasonable because we will have new tasks ahead of us, and the area of defence will come to us. Having just heard the Lord, you will see that they want conflict between European states, not friendship and peace. We want friendship and peace. That is why defence policy must also be designed jointly, but we must also be concerned about research, science, innovation, climate change, digitalisation. Even though I am very proud of Bavaria – the sky just extends beyond Bavaria, and that means in this realization that this sky does not stop at Bavaria, that we have a Europe-wide sky that goes even beyond that. In other words, we must conduct European research. The Horizon Europe research programme is one of the best. The Council has already been able to agree on the substance of this issue. We are also making better progress in understanding the substance within the Council than before the last MFF. But there is a lack of money. I am not one of those who constantly says that it has to be more. But if there are new tasks and more tasks, then there will be no choice but to provide some of the financial resources. I believe that Parliament's position is very consistent in this respect.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: "Dear friends, in order to win the battle for the climate, the European Commission tells us that between 175 and 290 billion euros are missing every year - these are the Commission's figures. How can we win the climate battle if the European budget does not increase? And how to put in place a "job" shield that will protect employees of smaller companies from the next financial crisis, how to do it if we do not have more resources? It is absolutely necessary to increase Europe's own resources. When he came to office in 1933, Roosevelt had the courage to triple the U.S. federal budget. In just four years, Roosevelt tripled the budget by implementing effective taxation. Why not do the same in Europe? Over the past 30 years, the average income tax rate has been halved to 45%, and it has now fallen to 20% as dividends soar. Why not take up the idea of Jacques Delors, the idea of Mario Monti, of a real European budget financed by own resources, in particular a federal tax on profits? If we are to win the battle of climate and jobs, Parliament must indeed adopt this resolution and give itself the means to have a much more ambitious budget.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, dear colleagues. This Budget of Europe will be as important as I think none before it will be. The challenges facing Europe, but also the entire planet, are existential. The climate crisis, the destruction of biodiversity from the Amazon to the Slovak forests, the tsunami of plastic waste, but also a cocktail of toxic substances all around us. However, this threat is also a huge opportunity. And this budget must match that. It is not just about what percentage of money we spend on protecting the climate or biodiversity. That must be the basis and it must be ambitious enough. Equally important is the coherence of policies so that the left hand knows what the right is doing. We cannot claim to be protecting the climate and nature when, at the same time, we subsidise its destruction. And that's still happening. Europe needs renewable energy, an industry that does not infest the environment, it needs agriculture protecting farmers, protecting both nature and animals. This budget is not about us. This budget is about whether our children will have a future. And we mustn't let them down.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I realise that a budget must look forward and that a budget must also provide for new priorities. However, we should not forget the Union's so-called 'old' policies. They have proved their worth, and it would be a mistake to save them dead, and that includes, above all, agricultural policy. We have a proposal on the table today. This proposal provides for significant savings in the field of agriculture, and even this proposal is not acceptable to some Member States. What is even more serious, in my opinion, is that the proposal provides for massive cuts, particularly in rural development. The rural development plan is now the most important rural development instrument for many regions. If this fund is now cut by more than a quarter, the richer states – those who, incidentally, do not want to pay what the Commission has proposed so far – will fill the hole with their own resources, and the others, the poorer ones, will fall by the wayside, and the Union will drift even further apart. That cannot be the point of a sensible policy.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, by voting in favour of this resolution today, we want to send a strong political signal to The citizens of Europe that their concerns have been heard. It is also a warning to the Council that we want to be a full participant in this debate on the future negotiations of the Multi-Year Financial Framework. Colleagues, funding our priorities on the eve of a difficult Brexit requires not only modernising, simplifying own resources, but also creating new ones. Only with an ambitious budget will we be able to meet the new priorities in terms of climate, youth employment, training, research and strengthening of the euro area. We also need an ambitious common agricultural policy to protect our farmers and their incomes so that they are able to produce healthy, sustainable, affordable and quality food that respects the environment.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. A quote from Oscar Wilde, who once said: "A cynic is someone who knows the price of everything and nothing about the value. For me, the populist cowardly cynics are those who delay, denounce investment as waste, block it and do not want to see the value of research and education, climate goals and investment, comprehensive agriculture and social cohesion, external border protection and security, defence, foreign policy, energy policy. Today's vote and the debate in the coming weeks is one between nationalism, populism, cowardice and ignorance, and on the other hand, responsibility, future, reason and sincerity. We all know that the 1% limit will betray our common future, for which each of us is responsible, and that it will conceal the added value of European decisions and investments from our citizens. I hope, Commissioner, that Parliament is on your side today and is backing you in the negotiations. We must make the future a friend.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, we all know that tourism has been a shared competence since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.  In November 2018, this plenary, in the resolution on Parliament's position with a view to or the next financial framework, was clear and approved the creation of a funding line for sustainable tourism and, to this end, asked the Commission to move forward immediately with a legislative proposal, a concrete proposal, as proof of respect for and recognition of this sector.  I regret that we have nothing to this day either from the Commission or the Member States.  I recall that in 2018 alone the arrivals of international tourists grew 6% worldwide. Tourism is undoubtedly a very important industry not only for my country, Portugal, but for the whole of Europe. This industry has contributed to a faster way for several countries to emerge from the economic and financial crisis.  Therefore, a final appeal to the Commission and the Member States: it is time to meet citizens' expectations. Let us make sustainable tourism a priority.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, Tudor Ciuhodaru my name, I am from Iasi, Romania. I believe that there are two (words that are not heard) being called into question, especially if we really want to meet the expectations of the citizens. Firstly, it is the quantitative part of this budget, and yes, indeed, it must be done in such a way as to cover as much as possible for all European citizens, to stop making those who are weaker at the moment pay for others.  But secondly, it is also the issue of how we distribute this budget. Romanians sent me to the European Parliament because they want regional hospitals, motorways and health, or equal subsidies to agriculture. Because you can talk about a lot of things, about development, about organic farming, about what investment in research means, but if we don't meet the fundamental needs of every citizen, these things cannot be achieved. I want you to enter into negotiations with the European Parliament, because remember, we are the ones that the citizens of Europe have sent to Parliament, and frankly, I will vote on a budget that will also respond to those at home and what all European citizens want. Thank.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: - Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner, I will say that even more challenging than Brexit is to find a new successful, modern economic model that Europe and all member states will use in the coming years. Indeed, the European budget must by no means be a strict, banking, but development, visionary budget with the aim that Europe has the highest GDP growth in the world, and citizens the highest growth in standards. To do this, we need to clearly define our strategic priorities such as education, digitalisation, green policies or security. And in all this, do not underestimate cohesion policy and its significance.  And I can't possibly accept the idea of a share growth from 15 per cent to 30 per cent of member states per approved project. That is why I expect one such idea to be stopped and that is why I believe in Europe, I believe in cohesion policy, solidarity of the Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, the Commission's proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework in smaller and less developed member states has, quite rightly, caused great dissatisfaction. The new priorities send a bad message – abandoning the reduction of development gaps between member states and redirecting common resources to objectives important to large and influential members. How else to interpret the reduction of cohesion spending while strengthening the role of cohesion policy in the long-term integration of migrants? I come from Croatia, a country that primarily has problems with the emigration of young and working-age populations. We need more cohesion funding to reach the European standard. It is also important for us to preserve life in rural areas and raise the competitiveness of agriculture, which with less allocation for the Common Agricultural Policy we will not be able to. This proposal cements the current situation and divides the Union into first-class and second-rate members. This division is absolutely unacceptable to me, and it should be to all of us in this home.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – This is an asymmetric integration in the distribution of the benefits and losses of the single market, common policies, the single currency. One and the other always fall to the same side.  The European Union budget should be to combat divergence, counter the asymmetric effects of integration, promote real convergence. I say it should, but it doesn't and it doesn't because cohesion has never had the means to do it.  Nevertheless, instead of strengthening cohesion, they now want to strike a major blow, the same is to say that it delivers a strong blow to countries such as Portugal, for which cohesion has the greatest significance. All this to further benefit the net beneficiaries of integration: the great European powers that are now launching into a dangerous security and militaristic drift that they want to finance with the European Union budget at the expense of cohesion.  Now this is a path that must be rejected. The resolution we are discussing, unfortunately, does not do so with the firmness that was necessary; on the contrary, it legitimizes it.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have always advocated a tight budgetary policy. For me, this has been the case as a local councillor, it has been the case as a member of parliament and it now also applies as an MEP.  For my party, it was a clear promise to the voters not to allow the EU budget to swell more than necessary, which would mean a substantial increase in the Swedish EU levy. The proposal now on the table risks implying a 40% increase in the Swedish levy and goes much further than I can accept.  Europe has major challenges ahead of it, not least in terms of competitiveness. It would then be wrong to burden our citizens and our entrepreneurs with even higher taxes to finance increased EUROPEAN contributions. On the contrary, I believe that the budget must be modernised and made more efficient. We should invest more in research, infrastructure and efficiency improvements that build growth. Then europe can really make differences in people's lives.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, Madam Minister, these are troubling times. Europe is about to go through one of its most challenging moments due to an irresponsible government in the UK that is willing to risk everything just for electoral reasons. This has been the case with the Conservative Party in the UK for a number of years now.  The European Council therefore has to decide how we face this situation. The economic risks for the EU are significant ones. The downturn is coming, and we need to provide a strong budget now so that we can provide confidence to investors and promote growth in cohesion and the EU. Instead, we face several members of the Council that want to cut the proposed budget even further. As the President of the Commission has said, it is simply not enough. We have finally just now had a Member of this Parliament – coming from the EPP – defending the same position as these Members of the European Council. It is clear now from where these kind of positions come. These are not acceptable. We need more Europe. We need to face this situation with more Europe, not with less budget as proposed by several members of the Council.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Minister, dear Members, I have listened with great attention to your interventions today. They all demonstrate that the huge majority of the European Parliament is fully committed to making the next EU long—term budget modern, ambitious and future—proof. You rightly underline in your resolution that now is the time to decide. We cannot afford to lose time and risk any damaging delay in the start of the next generation of programmes. We owe it to our citizens to provide predictability on the way the Union will respond to modern challenges, in particular in areas such as digital, climate action, border management and defence.  I would like to thank the Finnish Presidency for its paper for Coreper yesterday that is meant to prepare the debate of the October European Council on the next Multiannual Financial Framework. While we welcome the fact that the paper has been produced, we are – to be very clear from the start – very disappointed about the main elements of the content. There is an important gap to bridge at this point of the discussions between the institutions. We have to acknowledge this. But we call on the Council Presidency and the leaders to take full account of the positions expressed by the European Parliament. The Commission is fully committed to work closely with all institutions and to facilitate dialogue. I look forward to working with the European Parliament and its negotiating team and to bringing the MFF negotiations to a timely and successful conclusion.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, dear Commissioner, thank you for your valuable views, your pertinent questions and your clear observations.  Many of our common key challenges have been mentioned here today in this debate. I’d like just to list innovations, climate change, investment, sustainable agriculture, cohesion and last, but not least, the rule of law and respect for our common values. It is self-evident that these are our common interests – common interests of our institutions, common interests of our European citizens. They are our common challenges, and they need to be reflected in our common budget. The next MFF needs to respond to these common challenges.  The MFF is not just an accounting exercise. It is an implementation tool and an enabler for our political decisions. But at the same time, we need to be aware of the contributions which need to be made by the Member States. These contributions need to be fair, feasible and acceptable for all of the Member States.  Let me reiterate our Finnish Presidency’s firm commitment to regularly meeting the European Parliament’s negotiation team ahead of General Affairs Council meetings. In addition, the trilogues have already resumed on several sectoral files, and we are very much interested in hearing the Parliament’s position on these.  I would like to point out that, here today in this very plenary hall, we are debating the MFF together; we are exchanging views on the next financial framework. So we will not adopt the new MFF without our common efforts to ensure that our budget is fit for the new period. Thank you very much for this debate, and our work continues.

name: Nicola BEER
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, three motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Thank you very much, Minister, and a good hand now also at the discussions in the next Council! Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – The new Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2017 should give an answer to the big challenges ahead of us in Europe. It puts facts and numbers on the vision and priorities the EU wants to deliver and achieve. When people see the numbers, they realise what is deliverable and achievable, and what’s not. I welcome the fact that the Commission is proposing significant increases in funding for research, development and innovation. These are indeed positive investments for the future. But I deeply regret the drastic cuts to the common agriculture policy (-15%) and cohesion policy (-10%). For the most recent members of the EU that haven’t yet reached the pace of the others, funding to the agriculture sector is and will be an essential element in my final assessment of the MFF. If we want to have an ambitious, green, sustainable PAC and if we want our farmers to survive further competition coming with the Mercosur deal, for example, we need to support this core backbone of our societies. If we fail to do so, we might face the big risk of Euroscepticism arising in rural areas of Europe, which might feel abandoned by the institutions they look up to today.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Writing. – If the UK leaves the EU, the other trees will bear even more fruit, as the EU budget is expected to increase, even though a good €10 billion will be missing in the future. Germany, which already contributes more than €25 billion, more than a fifth of the EU budget, is the result of a large additional cost. If The UK leaves, the German contribution will increase by at least a quarter. For Germany, the budget contributions are only peanuts, not because Germany is so rich, but because the total cost of the EU is much higher. Since 2010, German taxpayers and savers have not only paid EUR 25 billion, but also between EUR 135 billion and EUR 174 billion a year for the euro rescue. The lion's share of these costs is accounted for by approximately EUR 36 billion in lost interest income for savers, around EUR 90 billion in target loans and up to EUR 400 billion of default risk for the bonds of more than EUR 2 trillion accumulated by the ECB since 2015. In total, Germany subsidizes the EU and the euro with between 160 and 200 billion euros per year. The cost of the euro and the EU budget for the other EU Member States is at least as high. In total, the EU and the euro cost EU citizens at least around €400 billion per year.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The proposal for a Financial Framework 2021-2027 (MFF) is unacceptable in its current form. The European Commission's draft sets double standards and would also significantly reduce regional development and agricultural resources. Hungary, it is unacceptable for our regions to suffer a 24% loss of resources. The proposed 16.4% cut in direct payments for Hungary in the Common Agricultural Policy and the 26.6% loss of resources in rural development support are completely unacceptable to us. We cannot accept the introduction of any new element in terms of the fitness of the EU budget; the rule of law, migration and the social pillar. The new rule of law mechanism to be introduced by the Commission circumvents the Contractual provisions and creates duplication with existing instruments.  We reject the linking of Community resources to subjective so-called rule of law conditions, which can be used as political punishments, and the punishment of regions that perform well economically in terms of job creation on political charges. EU development funds are not compassionate donations. The Hungarian regions are entitled to these resources on the basis of objective criteria. No EU institution should be allowed to see development resources as a means of exerting political pressure. Unfortunately, the proposal by the Finnish Presidency of the EU does not contain any acceptable improvements in these areas for Hungary, and is even less ambitious in terms of the total amount of the budget than the European Commission. It is particularly outrageous that it would reduce regional and agricultural resources, which have been significantly cut back, even further.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – I support the resolution on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, by which the European Parliament once again calls on the Council to unblock negotiations on this dossier. The EP has already established its position for more than a year and is awaiting dialogue with the Council. For the first time, on my proposal, the European Parliament has introduced figures with budget allocations for each area and European policy. The EP's priorities for the next 7 years are well established and some of them come to Romania's aid. For example, the EP rejects the Commission's proposal to reduce the funds allocated to cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy and will enter into dialogue with the Council with a mandate to maintain the current funding of these areas. In addition, calls on the Commission to ensure that the new multiannual budget meets the new environmental objectives, through financial allocations that ensure a fair transition to a zero-carbon economy, so that there are no disadvantaged areas or regions.  The May 2019 elections demonstrated citizens' attachment to European values and institutions. The EP is obliged to report to the Council that the blocking of negotiations on the MFF 2021-2027 carries the risk that the budget will not be voted on in time and that the beneficiaries of EU programmes – that is, European citizens – will not be able to continue their projects.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – 200 million European citizens voted in the 2019 EP elections, clearly formulating their expectations of the EU in the public debates of the election campaign. It is the duty of all the European institutions, but first of all it is our responsibility, the EP, to meet these expectations of greater safety, efficiency, sustainability, jobs and a prosperous future for Europe. This responsibility also implies the clear message that we are giving to the European Council today: the post-2021 MFF must be sized in such a way as to ensure that all European projects and policies, old or new, are carried out. The EP will not agree to the post-2021 MFF project unless it ensures adequate funding for cohesion and regional development policies, and the common agricultural policy, including Pillar 2, rural development. For all this, we need new budgetary resources. We call on the Commission to urgent legislative proposals based on the documents adopted in the EP. We also note with concern the delay in the development of the MFF. We therefore call for the urgent composition of the transitional provisions for 2021 so that no farmer, european company and beneficiary of European funds will encounter difficulties in the transition to the new post-2021 MFF.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Yana Toom's report on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the employment and social policies of the euro area (2019/2111(INI)) (A9-0016/2019). Before I open the debate, I would like to inform you that we are still testing a new system whereby Members can register spontaneous speeches and blue cards electronically. You have received information by e-mail about using this system and the instructions are on your table. Members may use the function keys on their electronic voting systems to submit a request for a speech. Please note that, in parallel with the use of the electronic system, a "standard registration" (by raising a white sheet of paper or by personally registering with colleagues in plenary at the beginning of the debate for spontaneous speeches and by lifting up a blue card for the blue card procedure) is also possible. I would therefore politely remind you to bring your voting card so that you can use this system. If you want to register an impromptu speech, you can do so now. You do not have to wait until the end of the debate.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, I’m happy to introduce the report on employment and social policies in the euro area, which was widely supported in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Coming from Estonia, I can be proud that, during our Presidency of the Council of the European Union, our Prime Minister, Jüri Ratas, had the privilege of co-signing, with Jean—Claude Juncker, the European Pillar of Social Rights. That was on 17 November 2017. This ambitious document, supported by the European Parliament, sets out important principles that we will have to implement now in the Member States. I have to thank Commissioner Thyssen for her hard work on improving social policies across the Union. We all know that this is not easy: every time, when it comes to social standards across the Union, somebody says ‘No, no no’, and refers to the principle of subsidiarity. At the same time, we all know that the situation is far from ideal. Since 2012, in the context of the European semester, the Commission has been issuing country-specific recommendations, not only on economics but also with regard to social policies in the euro area. This is an extremely important process but unfortunately – and this is reflected in the report – the rate of implementation of these recommendations is unacceptably low. Whereas at least some progress, or what was termed progress, was reported concerning 72% of country-specific recommendations in 2012, the figure decreased to 39%, the lowest rate ever, in 2018. So we are asking the Commission to take measures and find a way to convince Member States that the social health of the European Union is not less important than defence, the single market, or whatever other common policy of the Union. We are also asking them to consider extending these recommendations to non-euro states. I was happy to hear the new head of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, during her speech here before she was approved by Parliament, promising that, during the first 100 days of her term of office, she will come up with new legislative mechanisms to ensure for Europeans a fair minimum wage. For those who are sceptical, I have to underline that this proposal will take into account national traditions and legislation, which means that nobody is going to violate the principle of subsidiarity. The thing is that we have to fight so-called ‘working poverty’, and help people who live at the risk of poverty and social exclusion, otherwise we will end up in Europe with brain drain and depopulated areas, on the one hand, and more protests and Polish plumbers, on the other.
