During their hearings, several Commissioners-designate referred to a bill of social rights as a universal tool to solve the problems of depopulated regions and rural areas, but we also have people with disabilities, we have a gender pay gap, we have minorities facing discrimination and people at risk of poverty, and we have to help them. This is exactly what Europeans want, not only from national governments but also from us, the elected representatives in the European Union. In the report there is also a call for the Commission to create a new unemployment insurance scheme, which was warmly welcomed by trade unions. A funny thing that happened yesterday evening was that I received a letter from the European Confederation of Trade Unions in which they asked me to support my own report. When I answered them that this was kind of funny, they told me ‘No, no, you have to support this and that amendments.’  I really believe we’re standing for the right thing here, and, colleagues, I rely on your support.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Europe’s economy is in its seventh year of uninterrupted growth and today more people than ever have a job. Poverty is declining at a steady pace on the back of good labour market outcomes.  Europe is also stronger when it comes to our economic governance setting, and in particular the European Semester. We have managed to put social and economic policies on an equal footing, most recently by embedding the European Pillar of Social Rights. We are sharing good practices and have developed solid analysis and common understanding in close dialogue with the Member States and the involvement of social partners.  However, divergences persist across and within countries. While labour shortages increase in some countries, in others unemployment remains high. In—work poverty is still a major challenge, with almost one out of ten workers at risk of poverty. Atypical and new forms of work may have an impact on the segmentation of the labour market. In this perspective, a key priority must be to make labour markets more inclusive and to ensure all jobs created are of good quality. Furthermore, women remain at a disadvantage on the labour market, despite achieving better educational outcomes than men. Closing this gap would liberate a huge untapped potential with a positive impact for the economy and society. Ensuring effective work—life balance policies and access to childcare is crucial in this sense. In addition, technological change and digitisation are deeply changing European societies and economies. It is crystal clear that we need to step up investment in education, training and skills in order to properly accompany our people through these changing times, in order to harness productivity—enhancing technologies and also in order to ensure a just transition to a climate—neutral economy.  Indeed, bringing people to the centre of our policy—making is now more important than ever, because while poverty is finally declining across the board, at the same time we witness an increasing number of Europeans expressing a sense of vulnerability. This is triggered by income inequality, labour market precariousness, but also the uneven impact of globalisation and technological change among countries, regions, sectors and people. While investing in skills remains crucial to foster the inclusion of all people in tomorrow’s societies, social protection systems should be adapted to properly empower and protect our people. In this context, I want to thank the rapporteur and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs for this very balanced report. It presents well both the positive trends and the challenges ahead, and I broadly share its goals and conclusions.  Tackling these challenges, ensuring that we have a social market economy that works well for businesses and citizens, also in changing times, and fostering convergence is indeed the motivation behind the European Pillar of Social Rights. Less than two years since its proclamation, the implementation of the Pillar has already started. Its principles have been embedded in all the stages of the last two semester exercises, and almost half of the country—specific recommendations – 44% of which today address Pillar priorities.  Important legislative measures have been proposed and approved, implementing several principles of the Pillar, and EU funding has been re—geared to support implementation of the Pillar through an enhanced link between the semester and the programming of the European funds, notably the European Social Fund. Even more importantly, the Pillar has contributed to anchor job quality, investment in skills, social fairness and just transitions at the centre of the European agenda. Our Pillar of Social Rights is one of the main legacies of the outgoing Commission, but the work is far from finished, as we all know. Supported by the commitment of the European Parliament, the Commission, Member States and social partners, the Pillar is here to stay to act as a compass of our future action in the employment and social fields. Moreover, starting from the new cycle, the semester will be refocussed to integrate the United Nations’ sustainable development goals in line with the semester’s legal basis.  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, further efforts are needed to make our societies more inclusive and to prepare them for future changes. Stronger and more inclusive economies and societies would also strengthen the resilience of the euro area and pave the way for the deepening of the economic and monetary union.  As you all very well know, implementing the Pillar principles on the ground, as well as pursuing the sustainable development goals, is a joint endeavour which will be pursued both at the national and European level. I am sure that the Commission will remain at the forefront to promote upward convergence of social and living conditions throughout Europe and support people, businesses and regions in these changing times.

name: Maria WALSH
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking rapporteur Yana Toom, of Renew, and my other colleagues for their hard work and cooperation on this report, especially my colleagues in the PPE Group. It is vitally important that we all have well-performing social and economic policies, that these policies are not contradictory and that we move in the same direction. This report has continued to draw attention to the need for action on some persistent problems that we face in the EU. We need to take stronger action to reduce youth unemployment; tackle poverty, especially child poverty; increase labour market participation; achieve equality for each and every one of our people in society; boost competitiveness; and also think about the future and how we are going to adapt our skill sets and social systems to the future of our work, especially in rural and urban areas. I believe these are the issues and themes on which we need to take action over the coming years. Today, 10 October, is World Mental Health Day, and something I’m happy to see in this report is a call for us to take concrete measures to address mental health. It is regrettable that the EU focus on mental health has, in fact, lessened in recent years, despite its significant individual and economic cost. I think this should be a priority in employment, health and social policy. We are not looking after our citizens’ health if we are not looking after our mental health. Parliament, the Commission and the Member States all have the capacity to take action to improve mental health policy in the EU, and this report calls for specific measures including mental health promotion and prevention measures. During the recent hearings of our Commissioners-designate for both health and jobs, they too pledged to work hard, and I look forward to working with them, as does this Parliament, in the coming years. Finally, I’d like to thank again our rapporteur, Yana Toom, for her hard work.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, Europe must be more than a single market. Europe must be there for people who want to work on their future. We know that our work, not only through new technologies and economic developments, but also through the transition needed because of climate change, will change at a breakneck pace. Whether you're from Spalbeek, Split or Stockholm, all Europeans have to deal with this. So we have to prepare well so that everyone in society can participate and contribute. Mr Toom's balanced report that we are voting on today contributes to this process. We therefore call on the Member States and the European Commission to give platform workers better social protection, to quickly put an end to the great injustice of the gender pay gap doing the same work, to give older people a better view of new work, to give young people prospects for affordable housing and to facilitate disabled people and to ensure that they can flourish in the labour market. We want to invest in new jobs and training so that people can look forward to their future with confidence. Fortunately, the new President of the Commission has already embraced our idea that we should assist people when the economy is struggling economically. However, we still need to get the Member States involved. If we work together, we can combat long-term unemployment and support vulnerable regions. Then people can be sure that Europe works for them too.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Tom for this excellent report. I am pleased that the European Parliament is overwhelmingly in favour of this report on euro area employment and social policies, which follows the country-specific recommendations published by the European Commission last June as part of the European Semester. The general guidelines of this report reflect the strong interest of the new assembly in moving towards more social Europe with an emphasis on investment. I want to make two points. First of all, the European Commission's request to present a legal instrument so that every worker in the European Union can benefit from a fair minimum wage, respecting national traditions, is a major point for me. It has been enshrined in the political orientations of Ursula von der Leyen as a priority for the upcoming legislature in terms of social convergence. It is also one of the answers, it seems to me, to the labour shortage problems faced by most Member States. My second point concerns the workers of the platforms and their working conditions. We know that the work done in the European Union through online platforms - and this is a good thing - has increased by more than 25% in the last two years and now affects almost 5 million Europeans. While several Member States are setting up national measures on individual basis, it is time for the European Union to set the course. We must develop coordinated action to ensure the social protection of these workers and to guarantee all their social and labour rights.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her great work and cooperation on this file. We, as Greens, are happy with the report as it stands, especially because it covers several social issues which we believe should be addressed in the coming mandate at a European level. We are very pleased to see that the report supports giving the Union’s social goals a much higher priority, both when it comes to the coming legislative framework from the Commission and also when it comes to financial resources within the next budget. Another important aspect to address from a Green’s perspective is the importance of combating gender inequalities in the labour market. We are therefore pleased that we, with this report, make it clear to the Commission that we want a proposal for a directive on pay transparency in order to once and for all close down the unacceptable gender employment and pay gap that we see across the Union. The same goes for the pension gap.  Finally, we are very pleased that the report pushes for a solution to tackle long-term unemployment, brings focus to the inclusion of people with disabilities in the labour market, and – last but not least – calls for initiatives at European level to ensure platform workers’ rights and social protections, regardless of their employment status. These are all areas where we’ll keep a close eye on the Commission’s legislative actions in the months and years to come.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Ladies and gentlemen, Madam Rapporteur, no, the European Union is not getting better and comparison, Madam Rapporteur, is not right. The European Union is made up of perfectly disparate economies, with social, economic and regulatory situations having nothing to do with each other. This report, on the other hand, is full of ideology and bias that are reflected in the inclusion of Turkey in your data and this constant concern for the integration of emigrants into the labour market, to the detriment of our most modest compatriots. We will therefore, of course, vote against this report and support the alternative resolution of our colleague Guido Reil because it is much more necessary to restore its sovereignty to States in terms of economic and social policy, and because it is just as necessary to enable them to put a priority on employment for European Union nationals.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the beginning, of course, I thank everyone who created this document for their creative, intensive work. I would remind you that it concerns the euro area in particular, it is an appropriate but systematically repeated diagnosis of the market and social policy. We are talking about poverty, about unemployment, about the plight of young people, about education that is not adapted to the labour market, about an ageing society and that societies are not keeping up with revolution 4.0. There are no ideas or solutions. I hope that we, together with the Commission, will discuss this. I would like to point out that a great many of the provisions of this report go beyond the scope of the euro area, and are a major interference with the legislation of the Member States. I hope that when the Commission develops further documents, we will be able to talk seriously not only about diagnosis, but about how to solve problems.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the social and employment policies that have been implemented in the euro area countries have been subjugated to a treaty that is designed to criminalise any left-wing or progressive policy. Social and employment policies in my country, since our support for the euro, have meant social regression, income destruction, reduction of working class rights, mass emigration, charity and welfare. That is why we do not agree with socialising views of the European Semester and economic governance. Country-specific recommendations also highlight this path.  As it is said in my country, we cannot have sun in the thresher and rain in the nabal, that is, we cannot want to end poverty and social exclusion, promote the general increase in wages, ensure a public network of free and universal access daycare centers, end the scourge of youth and long-term employment or guarantee a dignified life for our elderly and, at the same time, defend the draconian rules of the euro.  For us, there is no doubt. The continued and sustained rise in labour and social rights, the standard of living of those who have less and less can, will only be achieved when it breaks with the constraints of the euro with the Fiscal Treaty and the Stability and Growth Pact. (The speaker refuses a "blue card" question from Tomáš Zdechovský)

name: Chiara GEMMA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of income support policies by many countries, such as Italy, is already having a real impact on the weakest sections of the population, but poverty levels and the increase in economic inequality remain unacceptable. Austerity policies have particularly affected those who are already in difficulty, and among them I like to pay particular attention to people with disabilities. The UNITED Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities noted with deep concern the negative impact that austerity constraints have on decent living standards, stressing the urgent need to stop these restrictive measures in order to guarantee them a higher quality of life. My commitment will be constant and will go in the direction of a social protection plan, which fully guarantees a decent standard of living and above all respects their right to difference and not to equality.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, iammy very much to the rapporteurs for the work that has been presented here, which makes it clear right at the beginning of the parliamentary term that we want to continue courageously over the next five years on the path that Jean-Claude Juncker began to pave five years ago. I do not want to make any secret of the fact that there is a differentiated position in my group on the instrument of unemployment reinsurance and that my own delegation – the German delegation – has a critical attitude on this. Nor do I want to make any secret of the fact that we in my group are very critical of the more extensive instruments that go beyond that. However, we will vote in favour of this report today because the fight against youth unemployment, fair working conditions and poverty in the European Union is something that is, of course, deeply rooted in the DNA of the PPE-DE.  We will be arguing about details here over the next five years – we must – but we will not be arguing about one thing: the direction. This is clear to our group, and i agree with that.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is absolutely positive, good and effective. It highlights the still worrying characteristics of the European labour market, but at the same time strongly confirms the target of 75 % as an average employment rate.  It is hard to see why fundamental innovative measures are being called into question, such as the supplementary scheme to combat unemployment for many European citizens, which, among other things, Ursula von der Leyen has already included in her first hundred days. I even hear the call for a financial instrument for external shocks and business crises being called into question. Instead, we need more Europe, a Europe of work, a social Europe. We need a return to that Amsterdam strategy, the European employment strategy of 1997, because Europe cannot just be economic, but must be a Europe of work and social life.

name: Katrin LANGENSIEPEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has There are reports that come at the right time, identify the right problems and call for committed action. The report by the rapporteur, Toom, is one of them. Hartstikke thanks daarvoor, mevrouw Toom. I would like to highlight the aspect of the disadvantage of people with disabilities, not only out of personal concern, but rather because this is a structural maladministration in the area of employment. The report explicitly states and deplores the disadvantage of people with disabilities. Above-average unemployment and high long-term unemployment speak for themselves. Access, inclusion and participation are human rights. The European Union ratified the relevant UN Convention in 2010. Equality and non-discrimination must therefore be a priority. The report highlights this. Economic policy and social policy in the EU must go hand in hand, and the social budget must therefore be sufficient for this.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Europe is colourful and diverse, and Europe is very different nationally and regionally, and that must remain the case, that is our strength. Centralism and planned economy in the Soviet Union have never led to prosperity and freedom, and that is why we reject European unemployment insurance. Labour markets in Europe are completely different from one region and we need regional solutions. We are also opposed to the European minimum wage. We stand by the German minimum wage, but a European minimum wage would lead to massive distortions of competition. We also reject the European guarantee on child poverty. Of course, we must combat child poverty, as is clear. But there are already three funds and they have fizzled out, they have brought nothing. I myself was affected by poverty as a child – in my native city of Gelsenkirchen, most of the poor children now live in Germany, and something has to be done about it. But we cannot always try to solve these problems with money, we are creating completely false incentives here. The poor get children, that's the problem. We need to get these people into work. This is how poverty is combated. Social is not the one who distributes other people's money. Social is the one who works a lot.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Social policies require a number of timely challenges; we must tackle the problems of an ageing population, digitalisation and the changes they bring to the labour market. Europe has been ageing for decades, with the share of people aged 65+ increasing in all Member States. This is obviously the effect of a longer life, and well, but also of lower fertility, and it is wrong. Europe is facing demographic old age with problems such as the feminisation of ageing, the singlerisation of ageing – and we therefore need to develop a strategy for the quality and accessibility of long-term care systems. It is a pressing need to make more investments, but this is also the labour market, so we need to look at what the standard of work is. Finally, Commissioner, thank you very much for your cooperation so far.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that we can support this report, which says everything and the opposite of everything. The right call for investment in social policy, employment and training is countered – I read paragraph 2 – by 'the Commission putting the necessary pressure on the Member States to implement the country recommendations', which are nothing more than those austerity policies that lead to cuts in the welfare state, essential services, the inclusion of the least and the disadvantaged. This is a major political contradiction which is no longer acceptable in European policies. It is not enough to talk about the minimum wage and youth unemployment if we do not allow investment in people's growth, well-being and quality of life.  We tabled amendments in committee, many of which were accepted, but unfortunately they were not enough to change the liberal and progressive imprint that the citizens of Europe, by their vote, have asked us to erase in favour of development, solidarity and opportunities for all. Therefore, the 5-Star Movement declares its vote to abstain from this report, which continues to ignore the needs and expectations of European citizens.

name: Sara SKYTTEDAL
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When the social pillar was adopted, there were many of us who had some concerns about which legislative proposals would follow. In Sweden, our Social Democrats were crystal clear that it would never lead to our taxpayers paying for subsidies to other countries. They said our concerns were completely unfounded. In this election campaign, however, the Social Democrats, led by Timmermans, have made it crystal clear that the EU should control social security and that we should establish a European unemployment insurance system. The PPE and the Christian Democrats have consistently opposed such a proposal. Now we sit here and read the proposal, black and white. Thankfully, there is still no legislation in place, but the ambition of the Socialist Group is clear: our taxpayers should be able to pay for a lack of benefit systems in other EU countries. One might ask whether there will remain any incentive for countries to fully fund their own social security systems and carry out the necessary reforms, now that the EU is offering to foot the bill.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Sinjura President, day ir-rapport jitkellem dwar kundizzjoni economics aktar favorevoli fl-Unjoni Ewropea fejn ir-rata tal-impjiegi kompliet tiżdied. Pero', l-inugwaljanzi fil-ġid u d-differenza fid-dħul xorta waħda baqgħu jżidu d-distakk bejn dawk illi huma sinjuri u dawk illi huma fqar. L-in work poverty, standard of living dièents, impjiegi in pagi ta' kwalità huma l-akbar sphindi li għandna quddiemna llum il-ġurnata. Illum mhuwiex biżżejjed illi wieħed ikolla xogħol. Irridu naraw illi permezz tal-impjiegi li noffru liè-äittadini tagħna - huma in l-family tagħhom and jistgħu jgħixu ħajja dièenti. Għandna bżonn policy tas-suq tax-xogħol illi tkun immirata sabiex ittejjeb il-kundizzjonijiet tax-xogħol in toffri impjiegi ġusti u ta' kwalità liè-äittadini Ewropej. Għall-ewwel darba, permezz ta' dan ir-rapport in emenda li mexxejt øil quddiem, il-Parlament Ewropew ser ikun qed jaddotta l-prinæipju tar-Right to Digitally Disconnect. Dan huwa l-ewwel pass, iżda pass importanti ħafna sabiex noffru bilanè aħjar bejn il-ħajja privata in x-xogħol lill-ħaddiema tagħna.  Fil-bidu, meta kont bdejt nitkellem dwar dan ir-right to disconnect, dan kien kwaandażi suġġett tabù, iżda wara l-vot tal-lum, dan il-prinnäpju ser isir rakkomandazzjoni uffièjali tal-Parlament Ewropew. Qabel nagħlaq, nixtieq nitlob is-support ta' kull wieħed in waħda minnkom ukoll fuq il-European Unemployment Benefit Insurance Scheme in fuq l-istrument il-gdid illi mistenni jindirizza l-problema tal-qgħad fit-tul fl-Unjoni Ewropea.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, we should stop talking about the employment rates that have been achieved and we should look at the alarming studies telling us that we are not ready for the challenges of an ageing population and the climate and digital transformations. The cost of these transformations will come and we cannot deal with it only by increasing funds. According to the OECD, around 17% of jobs in the EU are at risk of being automated. The jobs threat from automation ranges from less than 10% in Finland to a shocking 33% in Slovakia, my country. One-third of the EU labour force has almost no digital skills. Transitions will affect the most vulnerable people in our societies. What needs to be done? Innovation, productivity growth and social rights are closely connected. Social Europe will flourish only if our economic policies create a perfect environment for it. We have the same goal, so I think we should stop basing our decisions on ideologies or political slogans, and we should start with data-based policymaking.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, first of all, let me thank Yana Toom for this report. I think that overall, when we look at it, it is, I would say, very good from my point of view.  However, let me do one thing to follow up here, and it is point 1. This is where Yana Toom actually says he wants a new financial instrument to address long-term unemployment to be introduced. But we do have a revised ESF that works well. We have the European Globalisation Fund. My question is: Where do we get the money for this new instrument that we want to set up here? So we weaken these two instruments, which work well and have proven themselves, and put money in the third instrument? Instead of simplifying Europe, we are trying to make Europe more complex and create something that competes with each other. I hope that this debate has answered this question, and that is why I personally cannot support this point, even if I support the whole report.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to my colleagues that I support this report, despite the undeniable existence of controversial and contradictory points in it. I believe that such controversial proposals will still be the subject of serious work in this Chamber and, accordingly, a political clash between different visions, different groups, often different countries with their national interests. I support the report above all because it places the main focus where it needs to be – on countries, on regions, on societal groups, but also on the individuals most vulnerable in today's labour market situation. It focuses without hiding the risks that the European economy and the European labour market face. As a representative of Bulgaria – the country, unfortunately, with the lowest incomes in the European Union and with some of the most vulnerable community groups in the European Union – I welcome this report and hope that its recommendations will enter into force.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the Commission says that social policies are on an equal footing with other priorities in the EU. I find this hard to believe. In the budget, Commissioner, defence spend is being increased from EUR 590 million to EUR 13 billion. That’s 22 times more. Why isn’t this money going towards fighting poverty and inequality across Europe? It’s a subsidy to the arms industry. People say that the Europeans need more security. You know what? They do. They need the security of a home. They need the security of a liveable wage. They need the security of affordable, good healthcare. That’s the security they need. And, if you are worried about the security threat from terrorism, well maybe you might put some control on arms exports from Europe. Maybe you’d get the European countries to stop bombing other countries and creating problems and destabilising other regions. That’s the way forward with peace, not filling the pockets of the arms industry.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, over the next five years the European project must be built upon a progressive platform that unites both economic and social issues. Without such a platform, there will continue to be discrimination and disparity in the workforce and in pay. We must lower income inequalities, ensure wage growth for the bottom and middle percentiles, design training and education fit-for-purpose for the fourth industrial revolution, as well as tackling the gender pay and pension gaps. The European Pillar of Social Rights is our project here in the Socialists and Democrats group, and this legislature has a historic opportunity to set the first-ever EU minimum wage. It is a basic human right to be paid enough in order to live. For sustainable economic growth, we must invest in people. The two are intertwined, and failure to acknowledge that will prevent us from tackling the great injustices that we currently face.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the Croatian Government and the Governor have very ambitious plans for our country to join the euro area. I don't share their enthusiasm and I don't think it's nearly the time to accept the common currency.  Croatia is far from the European standard, and we have, quite certainly, a new recession ahead of us, the scale of which we cannot predict. Some European regions still face long-term unemployment, but also depopulation, which is plaguing Croatia, for example.  I agree with the recommendation to shift taxation from labour to other factors that do less harm to sustainable growth. The revitalisation of passive ends cannot be without investment in infrastructure and stimulating tax policies and, therefore, spending taxpayers' money on stronger social measures will not give much result. The vast majority of people want to live with dignity from their work, not to live on socialism.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, we are talking about the employment and social policies in the euro area, and I’d like to deal with the latest European Semester report from the Commission in relation to Ireland, where, although it’s possible to present employment in Ireland in an optimistic light, the reality is, as the report reveals, massive amounts of transient work, zero hour contracts, casual work, bogus self-employment, a rise in precarious employment – no coverage for these people in terms of social security, which has an enormous impact on the quality of life in citizens. So the report, while recognising serious social ills, I have to say is undermined by the fact of the lack of political imagination in how to address it, because the world has changed; the types of industry and work have changed, and there’s a total disconnect between this and the EU structures and institutions in terms of how to deal with it. And even when a Member State tries to deal with it, they are gagged and bound by the fiscal restraints that are built in to our Treaties. So these problems aren’t going to be solved by technical fixes or incremental adjustors, but by a radical transformation and a break with the god of neoliberalism.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the panacea proposed today is the stricter implementation of the Commission's recommendations by country. However, under European Union directives, pension thresholds are further increased, social security is privatised — as a result of the WFP, pensions are reduced, collective bargaining is broken up, serious obstacles to trade union action are put in place, the right to strike is restricted and redundancies are liberalised. The European Pillar of Rights and the logic of the minimum guaranteed income have the effect of squeezing all rights downwards, particularly for young people and women. The average wage is falling; this is what the figures show. More than 100 million poor people live in the European Union, 20 million unemployed and 5 million homeless, while at the same time a third of the jobs created are flexible and do not meet basic needs. These are the results of the European Union's anti-labour guidelines, specialised by governments in each country, with the aim of supporting the profitability of the groups as there is a new capitalist crisis in the background. Workers in the European Union must collectively and organizedly respond through their class unions, putting on the agenda the fight for their modern rights to permanent stable work, collective agreements that ensure decent wages and limits and working conditions, as well as free care and insurance under the responsibility of the state.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear rapporteur, dear shadow rapporteurs, Members of Parliament, colleagues, and if I may say, dear friends, I would like to thank you for this constructive and rich debate. I’ve taken good note of your positions, your concerns, your comments, and I will make sure to pass them on also to my successors. This debate reaffirmed our shared commitment to social Europe and to what is the guiding principle of the social market economy: that economic growth and social progress are two sides of the same coin and that they are reinforcing each other. This principle must steer all our work going forward. Dear Members of Parliament, this debate is special for me for one more reason: as you know, it is also my last debate here as a Commissioner. This gives me the opportunity to thank you: to thank you for the good cooperation. Of course I expected nothing less, having myself served as a Member of the European Parliament for more than 20 years. Over the past five years we worked together constructively in a friendly way, putting all this – the interests of Europe’s people – first. Over the last weeks and months, I have been receiving many compliments that the EU has become more social- and people-oriented. I always reply that these compliments should be extended beyond me, and I share these complements with you, because good results are the fruit of honest and good interinstitutional dialogue and shared commitments. Results are ultimately why we got involved in public life: to deliver what counts for people and to do our part for a dynamic, inclusive and fair society and economy. And following almost 30 years in public life, I can say that I am proud of what we have achieved and very hopeful of what comes next. But don’t get me wrong. Important challenges lie ahead; we were just discussing them. And just transitions don’t happen automatically. But the guidelines of the new President-elect of the new European Commission, Ms von der Leyen, show that our successors will build further on what has been achieved on the basis of our shared values. So I wish you very constructive years, and be sure that you can always count on me as a close ally on your work for a social Europe. (Applause)

name: Yana TOOM
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I think that we are on the same item. I would like to thank everybody for this very fruitful debate. It was a very warm feeling to hear shadow rapporteurs thanking me for an excellent job. I have to do the same and thank shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation. I agree with Ms Thyssen that it is a remarkable social shift, even in this House, and it’s really good to know. I also want to say to those who are not going to support the report, claiming that it is too ambitious or not ambitious enough: just keep in mind – and maybe reconsider your decision – that, whatever we do in this House, it is always a compromise and there is no possibility to have a compromise which makes all of us one hundred percent happy. When I was working on the report, like, I believe, every Member of Parliament we have kind of key words. My key words were: labour market, unemployment, women in the labour market, children, fight ageism in the labour market, ethnic groups, disabilities, digitalisation and automation, online platform, workers’ rights, climate change and transition to the green economy, reduction of poverty, health care system, mental health. Yesterday somebody told me that my report is like a Christmas tree. For everything good against everything bad, this is not serious and this is not doable. I have to agree that this is a Christmas tree, but this is a Christmas tree of problems we are facing. So please make an effort and solve them.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The report on employment and social policy in the euro area, which has received broad political support from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, is an opportunity for the EU to move away from focusing on stability and (in particular) the growth on which the euro area is founded (e.g. through the Stability and Growth Pact). If we are serious about the economy for people, then social policies cannot simply be a appendend or a first aid to the side damage caused by participation in the global competitive race for continuous (economic) growth. Unfortunately, the appearance of the vice-president-designate and commissioner responsible for the economy for the people also shows that the future European Commission has recognised, at the declaratory level, the need to adapt the economy to climate change, but refuses or does not recognise the fundamental incompatibilities of the concept of continuous growth with sustainable development and a social union that, together with economic union, is supposed to create a European economy for the people on an equal basis. The European economy for people must come from the people, not from maintaining the existing model of the market economy. The economy for people is an economy of quality jobs in which people get involved according to their potential and that allows for a decent life for all. At the same time, it caters to those who are unemployed or in the face of personal circumstances unemployed or not fully employed.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The social and employment policies that have been implemented in the euro area countries are largely determined by the neoliberal armour of the single currency, i.e. they are, in fact, anti-social policies and promoting unemployment, underemployment and precarious work.  These realities have grown significantly with monetary integration into the euro. These two decades are characterized by a sharp social setback, the degradation of labor income (and concomitant growth in capital profits), the attack on the rights of the working class, mass emigration, charity and welfare.  The building of the single currency has been growing - The Budgetary Treaty, Economic Governance, European Semester - and today it deeply constrains the continuation of left-wing policies, or even democratic policies, of a progressive nature. Any socialising visions of the European Semester or Economic Governance, of the anti-social wall of the euro, such as those that have been striving to spread social democracy, are nothing short of a hoax. You can't serve two amos. We must not want to end poverty and social exclusion, promote the general increase in wages, end the scourge of youth and long-term unemployment, guarantee a decent life for pensioners and pensioners and, at the same time, defend the draconian rules of the euro.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – The financial crisis of 2008 was deeper in Hungary than in most European countries, and this was largely caused by spending on irresponsible promises made by the then left-wing government. Today, a decade later, thanks to the tenacious work of the Fidesz government, the Hungarian economy is much more shock-resistant, less vulnerable than it was before previous slowdowns and crises in the world economy.  Now that the country is on a growth trajectory, we must be very careful about our achievements. We must prevent the left from fooling the electorate again with irresponsible and unsecured promises. The left is raising fantasies such as the European minimum wage and European unemployment reinsurance. It is doing so at a time when Brexit has caused the European Union's budget to fall. As a responsible politician, I cannot support ideas that seek to introduce a new financial instrument (i.e. new expenditure) and, moreover, limit member states' ability to respond rapidly to social policy challenges. I am pleased that the luxembourg commissioner-designate, Nicolas Schmit, who is otherwise socialist, clearly shares this view. You can't spend more with less money, every housewife knows that very well.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Writing. – Unemployment reinsurance as a new financial instrument would be another financial equalisation measure, as it were, through the back door. Solidarity between economically stronger and even less powerful Member States is crucial for the future of Europe and the prosperity of all citizens. In the interests of transparency with regard to financial flows, financial equalisation measures should be mentioned by name and should be seen in their entirety. To underline this, I voted against paragraph 1, Parts 2 and 3. Nevertheless, the overall report contains many useful ideas, such as measures to combat youth unemployment and age discrimination in the labour market. In addition, I am strongly committed to reducing the income gap between men and women and want to help people take full advantage of the opportunities offered by digitalisation. Extensive training is therefore essential. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the overall report.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: Writing. – The European Parliament has dealt with the budget for the next 7 years several times. It is important that the Finnish Presidency has put the issue on the agenda. And it is equally important that the debate is closed by the end of this year or early next year. The European Commission is proposing a smaller budget than before. The reduction would have a particular impact on cohesion policy, which would lead to a Hungary 20-25% for the first time. It's not accepted. I fully support Parliament's position that the EU budget should reach 1.3% of the common GPD and that cohesion and agricultural policy resources should be in real terms the same as before.  Similarly, I strongly agree that compliance with the requirements of the rule of law should be a prerequisite for the disbursement of EU aid. Governments that dismantle democracy, the independence of the judiciary, refuse to fight corruption – and even organise corruption – do not touch European taxpayers' money. Such governments should be excluded from the allocation of grants and replaced by direct support to municipalities, NGOs and businesses. The necessary procedures can still be found in the EU's budgetary rules. The Union has a duty to do everything it can to protect its citizens from the ups and downs of illiberal regimes. Taxpayers' money must be protected from corrupt politicians. However, this does not have to mean excluding entire countries from aid.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – this report by MEP Toom is important for the EU labour market. Social employment strategies require permanent change and adaptation to changing economic conditions. The report highlights the most important issues that require action by the European institutions. It is still worrying that there are significant differences in employment rates between Member States, regions and social groups. Long-term challenges such as ageing, digitisation and its impact on work still require urgent solutions. Effective policies are therefore needed that cover different forms of employment and adequately protect workers from abuse, discrimination and continuing poverty. Let us bear in mind that long-term unemployment particularly affects young people, single parents, long-term sufferers, people with disabilities or people with health problems who still face specific barriers and discrimination at all stages of employment in order to get a job. In addition, an increase in the number of temporary or unstable forms of employment can have dangerous consequences for the adequacy of pension benefits, especially for younger generations, whose careers often have gaps that can lead to the termination of contributions, also taking into account the stability of social security systems. This requires rapid changes to the law. Our priority must be to ensure decent jobs, access to adequate social protection, regardless of employment relationships or type of contract, wage increases and high-quality public services.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to take your seat. Good morning everyone. I would like to remind you that today is European and World Day against the Death Penalty. In a world where values and human rights tend to become relative, the death penalty is an affront to human dignity that cannot be tolerated under any circumstances.  This year we pay special tribute to the children whose parents have been sentenced to death. I remain convinced that the death inflicted by the State can never constitute true justice. It is equally important to consider the traumas suffered by these children. That is why, more than ever, our Parliament is determined and committed to defending human dignity, as enshrined in our Treaties.  We will do all we can to bring us closer to the day when all countries abolish the death penalty. We owe it to future generations, we owe it to ourselves. I am sure that is the feeling of the whole Parliament. Thank you.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament has just adopted amendments to the Council’s position on Draft amending budget No 4 to the general budget for 2019. I take note of the differences in the positions of our two institutions concerning this Draft amending budget No 4 of 2019 presented by the Commission. Consequently, in my capacity as President of the Council, I agree that the President of the European Parliament convenes the conciliation committee, as required in point C of Article 314, paragraph 4, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Thank you Minister. The Parliament will now convene the Conciliation Committee, and we move on to the vote on the second report by Mr Howarth, by roll call. The vote is open.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I was a little hesitant on this objection. I would like to explain my vote. In the end, I voted against this appeal. Personally, I am not against the use of genetically modified foods, including, of course, maize, as long as strict criteria are met. In the EU, we have quite strict limits on food safety, on health, of course, and these limits must be respected unconditionally by everyone. Of course, when maize and its producers from other, third states are allowed access to the market, then these foods must also be safe. For this reason, I believe that our European rules apply and that this policy so far is correct. What I do not consider to be entirely correct, however, is that this maize is imported precisely from, for example, wooded and deforested areas in South America and causes very significant problems in the agriculture there, and I will also get to that on the issue of soybeans.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President. I am voting against today's three objections concerning the authorisation of genetically modified organisms for a number of reasons.   The systematic objections raised to date are not based on technical issues but on prejudices or emotional aspects, which omit the requirements set out in the rules of procedure for their submission. EFSA's risk assessment has been concluded in the analysis of these products that are as safe as conventional products.  There is a scientific consensus in this regard.  The Commission has an obligation to implement existing legislation, and this Parliament cannot support objections without scientific basis.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in that previous reply, I gave my opinion on GMOs, food.  In my opinion, the rules that we have in the European area work, they are strict, they are scientifically based. For this reason too, I voted against this soybean object. What I think is worth considering, however, is the question of how these products are grown in some third countries, for example, I mean Brazil in particular, where it is consumption and hunger for these foods in the European area that forces farmers there to burn the forest to some extent, and we then, of course, criticise this in the European area. Personally, I would like to support a policy that will keep both the issue of genetically modified food within reasonable limits and, of course, the sustainability of forestry and agriculture worldwide. We should therefore proceed with great caution in this matter.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, the number of cases of misinformation attributed to Russian hackers and identified by East StratCom has practically doubled this year compared to 2018, reaching 1,000. The Kremlin's disinformation factory hits targeted. This month, for example, journalists in Romania discovered that a national news station had no less than five cloned pages on Facebook, with many Russian likes. Commissioner King, for his part, warned last month that the number of fake Facebook accounts stood at $20 million. Moscow is putting about one billion euros a year on the line for disinformation and propaganda. We have to do a lot more. I call on the future High Representative to now take on, as a priority, the transformation of East StratCom into a permanent and properly funded structure, and the future Commission must have a very clear agenda to combat misinformation, but also to educate the European public.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr As a representative of Latvia, I voted unequivocally in favour of the Anti-Disinformation Resolution, because the whole of Europe, and especially the countries that make up Europe's external border, must fight against disinformation and the interference of third countries in democratic processes in a permanent and coordinated way. Russia openly points to its policies to create a single cultural and information space in its non-countries, especially in the Baltic States, so Latvia has been implementing a complex plan to combat disinformation since 2016. And I also want to emphasise from my experience the need to work in complexes. It is essential to combat disinformation, but it is all the more important to work preventively, strengthening areas of importance for democracy and not only in the electoral years. Strong and reliable national media, especially editorially independent and well-paid public media, are essential aspects of the complex approach. But it is also particularly important to support commercial media and, in particular, local and regional media. It is also very important to think about other trusted news sources. Today, literally in parallel with our session in the Norwegian House, a conference is held, where encyclopaedia from several countries have come together, and this conference is permeated by the idea that we need to review the role of the encyclopedia in maintaining European democracy and to provide expertise ... (the sitting leader prevents the speaker from continuing to speak).

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, I voted against the motion, which I found to be a farce. The subtext is that Russia, China, Iran, North Korea and Venezuela are spreading disinformation that’s helping to fuel gains made by anti-EU extremist and populist candidates across Europe. Yet there is zero concrete evidence to support these claims, which the Commission report from June on the subject explicitly admits. This motion is itself part of a disinformation campaign against other states, part of a long-running record of NATO electoral interference. Take the record of our great NATO ally, the US, as a case in point. Since the end of the Second World War, they have endeavoured to overthrow more than 50 foreign governments, most of whom were democratically elected, openly interfered in democratic elections in over 30 countries, attempted to assassinate more than 50 foreign leaders, and dropped bombs – often with our assistance – on the people of around 30 countries.  What of the ongoing EU and US imposed sanctions against Crimea, Iran, Syria, Venezuela and North Korea – a form of economic terrorism. This weapon is used to hurt the ordinary people of these countries and very often they change their political position because of the pressure from the sanctions. That’s the worst of interference.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, I also voted against this text because in reality, as the previous speaker said, there is no evidence; there are innuendos, we are fuelling this climate of cold war. In the end, all those who are against the prevailing opinion, against, I would say, the constant praise of what the European Union is doing, find themselves condemned. I also voted against it because, in reality, it is very clear that it is all directed against two or three countries. I would like to remind you that in France, of course, Russia Today is broadcasting and that, until now, there has never been a finding of false information. Finally, the only false information we have had massively in France in recent years, I remember, was about Syria. It was false information conveyed by the state media: we were swept around a fake mayor of Aleppo to explain that Aleppo was in this or that situation, only to realize, a few months later, that all this had been totally invented.  When it comes to fake news, I don't think we have a lot of lessons to teach.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, the integrity of our elections is critical for the success in survival of democracy. A UK Government report concluded that we cannot say there was no foreign interference in the 2016 referendum. Anti-EU articles by Russian-backed media containing false information received widespread circulation, and in the UK our party-funding laws suffer terrible loopholes. Money can be donated by individuals and also by companies, not only companies in the UK, but those active overseas, and there is no practical way to be sure that money is not originated from another country or even a foreign government. Our newspapers are mostly owned by a tiny handful of people, many of whom do not even live in the UK. The need for reform is great. This is an issue on which Europe must work together.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, some terrible events this week, both in Europe and beyond our borders, remind us that seismic shifts are afoot with respect to what kinds of opinions are normalised. The unspeakable is becoming speakable, the unthinkable is being thought. Of the money funding hatred and disruption, some clearly comes from within the EU from our own oligarchical elites, but evidence is growing that some is from foreign sources.  We need powerful internal regulations about electoral funding, but we must also address the root causes – the rising inequality, the unseemly wealth of the few in our increasingly cruel and intolerant society – and we need powerful international tools to combat interference by enemies overseas.  I’ve signed this resolution and voted in favour because our EU was founded on a politics of friendship. We need to restore the hearts and minds of the European people to allow the voice of peace, of friendship, of unity and diversity, to be heard. That voice needs to come through in every conversation between sister and brother across our continent, but for it to be heard we must adjust the volume on the voices of aggression and fear.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, I want to make the specific point that we mustn’t be complacent about the question of foreign interference and the integrity of our elections. We specifically asked for a special committee of inquiry and this was narrowly defeated today. I very much regret this because colleagues have talked about hard evidence on this issue and that is exactly what we were attempting to do, to ensure that what we do is based on facts and that we protect our elections and the democratic will of our people, both in our Member States and indeed in cross-border elections. So this is an extremely important issue, given the increasing influence of disinformation, electoral fraud and reports of foreign interference in many of our Member States. Despite the fact that we don’t have the special committee, let us ensure that this House, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and our Commission –our Security Commissioner who has begun work on this issue – continue to do so and that we do not fall into complacency on protecting our elections.

name: Christian ALLARD
text: – Madam President, I voted for this amended resolution, but there is one point I would like to make to my colleagues. When we use the word foreign, I think we have to be a bit careful that we are not targeting individuals, as opposed to targeting those whom we should target, which are states and non-state actors from third countries. Why do I say that? Because we have a climate just now of intolerance across the world and in the EU.  I’m a foreigner in my own country, the country I represent in this Parliament. We are all foreigners to one another, but we have to try to avoid using this sometimes pejorative term of ‘foreigner’. Let me give you one example. We are, in the Scottish Parliament, putting forward a bill just now to extend the franchise to everybody who lives in Scotland to vote. Let’s share our democratic values that make sure people can vote whether they are foreigners or not if they live in our states.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I consider this debate and this resolution on external influence of elections and disinformation in national and European democratic processes to be very important, which is why I supported it. I also consider the part that calls on the European Commission to give greater support to both the East StratCom financial and personnel group, which deals precisely with the spread of disinformation, the fight against disinformation in this part of Europe. I am glad that the EP adopted this resolution by a large majority.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I voted against this motion because what does it say to and about voters? It says you were all duped; you had no agency to decide; you did not know what you were voting for.  Honest misinformation and fake news, we have heard far too much of it in this Parliament, including slanderous accusations in UK terms. Let me tell you now, Brexit voters did not vote because of Russian bots, or Facebook, but because we believe in sovereignty. I want a warning to my European colleagues about interference in European elections, which is a problem. The EU, sadly, interferes in nation—states’ elections. It interferes when they have referenda. Ireland, France, Denmark, UK; they say you got it wrong, vote again, vote again, vote again – until we vote your way! And what’s worse is this motion amounts to giving the EU the power to censor what we see and what we read. I vote against this motion because it gives more power to you and it attacks voters.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Madam President, I voted against this resolution. We just need to strengthen the democratic processes, but not by the means proposed. For example, to upgrade the EU East StratCom Task Force to a permanent structure entails significantly higher financing. In the very same resolution we find the justification – the doubled number of disinformation cases in 2019 when compared with the previous year. But the reason for that phenomenon is the doubling of the StratComm budget for this year, not vice versa. Demand creates supply. As a subscriber of StratComm mailing, I see hundreds of fake disclosures. For example, the story on Russian TV telling us that it is immoral to dissect an animal in front of children was mentioned as a case of disinformation. But it was a real case in a Danish zoo. In such a way, any criticism can be qualified as disinformation. Is this what we will spend millions of euros on?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, I supported the proposed resolution on external interference in elections and disinformation in national and European democratic processes. In recent years, we have undoubtedly witnessed numerous such cases of interference in both the European Union and the States. However, I cannot help but mention that there are also cases where intervention is not external to the Union. I am talking about these circles of NGOs, funded vaguely from where, who are trying to change the will of the nations, of the states that want to decide their own internal political processes. We have witnessed such processes in Hungary, in Poland, in Bulgaria even. We are witnessing groups of non-governmental organizations interfering in the elections in Bulgaria right now. Left, greens unite in defense of organizations like the Helsinki Committee, which protect frankly criminals and proven convicted murderers. And this is happening at the moment and these organizations are unacceptably interfering in the electoral process and trying to influence the will of bulgarian citizens, which I do not allow and object to.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I have unequivocally supported this motion for a resolution, although some of the means envisaged in this resolution are indeed questionable. In my opinion, what is not disputed is the fact that there are attempts by third states, third powers, to influence elections at national or supranational, European level. I think this is a fact. I would like to acknowledge, for example, the work of the Finnish journalist Jessica Aro, who documented the existence of a troll farm in St. Petersburg. So if anyone doubts it, as has been said here, I think the evidence is absolutely clear and it's the facts.  Look at how, very vigorously, these attacks on their free elections are being investigated by the United States. It is a vigorous investigation, I think the European space deserves such vigorous action. I support this as much as possible, we should, of course, also give support to the media, both public and commercial, share information and, of course, uncover these networks. That's very important.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I was stunned – as I’m sure many of you here were – to learn about the existence of the fake website of the European Parliament vulgarly named ‘EP Today’. According to the EU’s East StratCom Task Force which exposed the website, the majority of its content is republished from the Kremlin-based propaganda channel Russia Today, and this is clear evidence and a fact for those who still do not see and miss the propaganda all around.  We need to increase our citizens’ resilience and their capacity to distinguish fact from fake. In order to achieve this, we must boost our support to such actors as the team of the EU’s East StratCom Task Force, which tirelessly work to expose foreign interference and disinformation. Moreover, we must improve civic education and media literacy programmes and enable civil society organisations.  With these resolutions we rightly call for greater national and European attention, accompanied by the increased financial support for the activities I just mentioned. We also task the next High Representative of the Union to make the fight against disinformation a central foreign policy objective.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – (start of speech off mic) ... this resolution because we need to send this strong signal to the Council ahead of next week’s discussion, and yet I was extremely surprised to see that, although it was supported by the four main political groups of this House, there is not a single word in the resolution about the new financial instrument for supporting civil society, the rights and values instrument, and there’s not a single word in it about civil society. Traditionally speaking, this House – Parliament –has always been a supporter of civil society. They need a proper instrument, finally, to be able to follow their agenda. It is not acceptable for us not to mention and not to ask for more action in this area as a push ahead of next week’s discussion when the space for civil society is shrinking in countries like Hungary, Poland or Bulgaria, and even in my country, Romania.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, we were surprised this week by the european court's announcement that some EUR 300 billion of the European multiannual budget remains on the shelf. That is more than twice the full European annual budget. I therefore find it just as surprising that some members in this House want to increase the next multi-annual budget even further. Of course, Brexit has budgetary implications, but as far as the CDA is concerned, we also look critically at spending first. Where and why is money left on the shelf and what can perhaps be the end of it? New priorities don't necessarily have to mean more money. The European budget is not a Christmas tree in which everyone can hang their own project. There has to be a balance. We can only spend every euro once, so let's deal with it carefully. Not political gifts that must then be paid for by the citizen, but spend wisely and efficiently as they should. That did not happen in this case, which is why the CDA voted against this resolution.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I supported the position on the multiannual budget, but I wanted to raise two points. Firstly, in the context of a still unclear Brexit, I believe that the European Commission should draw up a contingency plan in case the UK leaves without a deal and, as a result, no longer pays any contributions to the joint budget from next year. I believe that a solution should be found here that will ensure the security of payments to beneficiaries of Union-funded programmes in all Member States, including the people of the Wielkopolska region in Poland, who have entrusted me with a mandate to the European Parliament. The second issue is the reform of the Union's own resources system. I am convinced that new sources of funding , in addition to the elimination of rebates and corrections, should include new fiscal solutions, including a digital tax. It should cover all internet undertakings which generate colossal profits in the Union but, unlike other participants in the internal market, do not pay the taxes due there, simply because their premises are located outside the Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I finally supported this resolution on the multiannual financial framework, despite the fact that I hesitated for exactly the same reasons as my previous speaker, Mr Lenaers, mentioned here. I supported it because I think the time factor here is important. We wanted to call on and therefore call on the European Council to reach an agreement with the European Parliament as soon as possible and for a stable budget to be adopted, because we all want to finance important programmes such as Erasmus, Horizon. We want to finance cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy, and there is a risk of a commission here. Of course, the decision on own revenues is also a condition for the budget to be realistic. I did not like the significant increase compared to the Commission's proposal, which proposed 1.11%, we are proposing 1.3%, I think there must be a reasonable compromise.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I voted against the resolution on the multiannual financial framework. The resolution is full of words about stability, the fight against climate change, and so on, but behind it lies a classic social plan. Besides other things, the draft resolution calls for the introduction of, for example, corporate taxes, digital services taxes, financial transaction taxes, VAT adjustment, etc. I understand this attention and these efforts among our Socialist colleagues. However, I am surprised by the attitude of many Members who consider themselves as centre-right politicians. It’s basically a call for a tax increase.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I supported the proposed resolution, which is part of the strategy of our institution, the European Parliament, to influence the negotiations on the next multiannual financial framework. The text contains a number of important elements that support parliament's position already expressed on the volume of the next multiannual financial framework. An undeniably important element in this document is the call for the establishment of an emergency plan. This plan would function as a safety net to protect beneficiaries and users of European Union funding programmes and would allow an extension of the current financial framework if the deal is not agreed in time.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, let me quote: ‘Employees are leaving left, right and centre, being suspended and sacked at every opportunity, it’s an awful environment to work in. The ballot results are in, and we’re going to strike.’ That’s a worker at Wilko in my constituency who will take industrial action tomorrow with their trade union, the GMB. Wilko’s used to be a good family firm with strong values and a commitment to the local community. Sadly, it has moved away from that and I want to give my full support to the workforce at Wilko’s taking action tomorrow against new working practices, against new working arrangements, which will force workers to spend less time with their families, more weekend work. This has been imposed on those workers in an atrocious, unfair way, and those workers, their trade union the GMB, taking that action tomorrow, have my full support.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, also here, in this case, I would like to explain why I ultimately voted in favour of this report. It contains proposals that I think it is important for the European Union to support from its level and put some pressure on all states not to have countries with different speeds. In particular, access to youth employment: here we already have certain European instruments through which Member States should and have the opportunity to support young people much more, such as Erasmus, the European Social Fund, the European Solidarity Corps. So it is just a point of european states being active. Equally important is the issue of education, quality, accessibility, mutual recognition of qualifications. I do not agree with the unification of the European unemployment insurance system, but I agree that there should be a certain level of coordination and the setting of common minimum standards. It's important.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this motion because despite the great sentiments on tackling unemployment and workers’ rights and benefits, there’s a big ‘but’. The EU likes to tell us that trade union rights and workers’ rights are guaranteed by the EU but that’s fake news. They’ve been historically fought for by millions of ordinary people taking on their bosses and governments, and yet you reduce these struggles to paternalistically handing out rights like crumbs with more bureaucracy added on. And also, isn’t it virtue signalling? How will all this rhetoric about rights go down in Greece and Italy and so many eurozone countries which have been punished by the EU, which imposed austerity, the misery of poverty and unemployment, and humiliated nation states by telling them they couldn’t decide on their own economic policies?  So I abstain because I agree with supporting workers’ rights and unemployment, but I don’t trust you lot to do it, I’m afraid, and I appeal to my fellow Europeans who support workers’ rights to not rely on the bureaucrats here in Brussels.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, the report is quite balanced. Its main focus is to incentivise Member States to strike a greater balance between economic and social dimensions. Some of the priorities in the text that I can support are promoting digital skills and entrepreneurship, especially in small and medium-sized enterprises. However, the same document reiterates calls for greater pressure on Member States and policies on migrants. Again, as I have discussed before, policies relating to illegal immigration, its promotion and, in general, those activities of non-governmental organisations, which I do not support and reject, are inserted into meaningful texts. Such texts clearly cannot be supported. I believe that the document also does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, i.e. the rights of Member States to decide their internal issues with internal legislation. Therefore, taking into account the positive aspects of the report, I abstained.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: I declare adjourned the session of the European Parliament.
